reviews.content: Just this morning, as I was flicking absent-mindedly through the television channels, I accidentally clicked my way onto Channel 31 (Australia), which, I hazard to venture, is not generally known for its quality programming. Luckily, my eye was momentarily caught by a young and sharp-looking Cary Grant, and I immediately identified the film to be 1940's 'His Girl Friday,' which I had been meaning to watch for some months. Just like Frank Capra's holiday favourite 'It's A Wonderful Life,' the film has fallen into the public domain, and so television stations are completely free to air it whenever they want. This also means that any company is allowed to throw a poor-quality print onto DVD at practically no cost to them, so this is something to be wary of. Unfortunately, I missed a few minutes of the beginning of the film, but I was too hooked into the story to worry about that until later.For his remake of the 1931 film 'The Front Page' (which was directed by Lewis Milestone and starred Adolphe Menjou), Howard Hawks took the story  complete with all its witty, rapid-fire dialogue  and changed the male character of Hildebrand 'Hildy' Johnson to a female  Hildegaard 'Hildy' Johnson (Rosalind Russell)  and also the ex-wife of the newspaper editor, Walter Burns (Cary Grant). When Hildy expresses her intentions of quitting the newspaper business and marrying Bruce Baldwin (Ralph Bellamy) in Albany, Walter takes every precaution possible to prevent her from boarding that train. With a convicted cop-killer, Earl Williams (John Qualen), set to be hanged in the morning, the press-room at the prison is abuzz with vulturous reporters scavenging about for a good story. Rather than simply admitting his continuing love for Hildy, Walter uses the great lengths to which he will go to stop her leaving to tell her how he still feels about her. Also, along the way, Hildy discovers  as the night gradually becomes more and more exciting  that she is a reporter at heart, and will never be able to rid herself of the desire to uncover that perfect story.The jokes come thick and fast, with the talented cast delivering the clever dialogue faster than you can register it, barely giving you any time to laugh. Especially in screwball comedies such as these, actor confidence is absolutely essential, and everybody involved here performs admirably. In addition to the entertaining and often-heated banter between Walter and Hildy, other excellent characters include Bruce Baldwin (the unfortunate would-be future husband whose is arrested on no less than three occasions, and whose mother is kidnapped), the bumbling Sheriff Peter B. Hartwell (Gene Lockhart), Walter's sneaky henchman, Diamond Louie (Abner Biberman), the governor's clueless delivery-man, Joe Pettibone (Billy Gilbert) and a long line of newspaper reporters, each of whom witnesses the same event and yet still reports it in a completely different and entirely inaccurate manner.

reviews.review_title: This movie has a very witty script! The situation comedy is just hilarious!
reviews.content: The most interesting thing about those old movies to me is how much action can happen in so little space.  Same thing happened in "Key Largo."  The most fascinating thing is how fast  those people talk, how fast  they move, how fast they talk and move, but they really don't go anywhere. Low budget and an action packed!!!  Leonard Maltin points out that this movie is a remake of a movie "The Front Page."  I thought the script was all new, since the movie is so old.  Well one cannot assume anything as far as Hollywood goes, seldom one sees a brand new script.  One should never take for granted a new script. That however, does not take anything away from this funny comedy.  I liked the movie, and I must confess that sometimes even the natives have problems understanding such fast paced English.  That is a clever idea because the audience feels that many facts are happening,   when in reality no one is going anywhere, and what we are seeing is just a very witty script.  I recommend it, and I believe that most people would enjoy it!  I also love those 1940's dresses that  Rosalind Russell wore in the movie. My favorite scenes": Walter Burns" Cary Grant (Father Goose, An Affair to Remember) framing the other guy "Bruce Baldwin"  Ralph Bellamy (Trading Places,  and 133 other movies) getting him into trouble all the time. The way "Hildy Johnson," Rosalind Russell,  (Auntie Mame, Gypsy) will be at Walter's by Friday. The situation comedy is just hilarious! Favorite Quotes: Hildy Johnson: "Walter, you're wonderful, in a loathsome sort of way." Bruce Baldwin: "Nice little town, Albany. They've got a state capital there, you know." Bruce Baldwin: " He's got a lot of charm." Hildy Johnson: "Yes, it comes naturally; his grandfather was a snake." This movie is a classic. It is so much fun! I recommend it. After you watch try to talk as fast as they did in this movie, ha!

reviews.review_title: You'll need an edition with crisp sound for this one - the words are all the substance. Plus, don't watch it if you're prone to stress or agitation.
reviews.content: Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell are two of my favourite screen personalities, but this movie's being 100% about the dialogue annoyed me, and the speed of the dialogue just made me anxious!If you don't like words and dialogue - don't see this. It is 100% dialogue. The words are all it is. The leads are just mouthpieces, the stagings very stagey and studio-based - what it has in abundance is words words words, a hundred miles and hour till they grate on your skull, itch at your skin and come out your mouth as you tell it "enough, stop!" This is what Stroheim feared movies would become - all talk, no cinema.Interestingly, the reason the talk grated on me was half how rushed and urgent it was, half the fact that i could only half hear it because it was a cheapie DVD with bad sound. The insight it afforded me was to point out to you all that the words are the artifice that this film consists of. There are many movies in this world that you could turn the sound off and not only still understand it, but have a ball of a time watching them: Lawrence of Arabia (1962), Touch of Evil (1958), The Searchers (1955) and 2001 (1968) spring to mind - but there are heaps of them. The best movies combine dialogue with pictures for a terrific experience (Citizen Kane, 1941 is one of the best).Everything cinematic was forgotten in this film, though, and Stroheim's worst fears for the end of silence and the coming of sound were proved true.If I can stand properly hearing the dialogue, i'll probably watch this again some time - but i did not enjoy it at all.2/5.

reviews.review_title: There's been a lamp burning in the window for ya, honey... here.
reviews.content: Ben Hecht's The Front Page has been made three times as far as I know. Billy Wilder's version is better that the original, and certainly better than the other four versions, but not better that this one directed by Howard Hawks and starring Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell, who, like John Wayne last month, would be 100 today.The repartee between Grant and Russell is fast and furious. You really have to pay attention to catch all the jokes because they do not take a breath the entire movie. It is fast and funny. These two are perfect together.It is interesting that this is the only version where Hildy is a woman. Maybe that is why it is the best version and a classic.

reviews.review_title: An unscrupulous editor plots to keep his star reporter and ex-wife from remarrying.
reviews.content: In this second film version of the hit play by Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur The Front Page, New York newspaper reporter Hildy Johnson (played by Pat O'Brien in 1931) is now a sassy, confident woman (Rosalind Russell). Hildy has had enough of the newspaper life and is going to quit and marry dependable (boring) Bruce Baldwin (never-gets-the-girl Ralph Bellamy) and move to Albany. The thing is, her editor and ex-husband Walter Burns Cary Grant) doesn't want either thing to happen and tricks Hildy into covering just one more story  that of a deluded radical charged with murder. What follows is a super-charged side-splitting satire of the headline-hungry newspaper business and of course, a bit of romance.Howard Hawks directs his stars and a brilliant cast of supporting players (Billy Gilbert, a real scene-stealing stand-out) at a breathless pace, using overlapping dialog to increase the feeling of frenzy. You'll want to watch this one again and again to catch all of the terrific dialog. Some of those witty lines (at least as legend has it) were improvised, such as when Grant describes Bruce Baldwin, saying that he "looks like that film actor, Ralph Bellamy." Later, during a rapid-fire telephone exchange, Grant responds to another actor's line with "The last person to say that to me was Archibald Leach just before he cut his throat!" (Archibald Leach of course, being Grant's real name.) Named to the National Film Registry in 1993.

reviews.review_title: Great play plus great performers=what else?
reviews.content: "His Girl Friday" is another of a long line of movie adaptations of one of the mainstays of comedy. There's a reason for this. The script is just simply hilarious. The characters could all come from a Marx Brothers or Monty Python movie, so don't look for depth, but they aren't one dimensional either. In fact, for a slapstick, down and out laugh-o-rama, this movie tries to instill a lot of depth into their characters. The plot is about the distinguished journalists of the era, and pokes fun at what they were really like. Everyone is out for a scoop, and will do anything to get it. Corrupt officials and an escaped soft spoken murderer make this even easier for the reporters. Cary Grant, of course, leads the stellar cast. He could make "Equus" look exciting, so give him a great screenplay, and he comes through. Of course all the movie versions were hilarious. It might depend on whether you prefer Grant or Mattheau. They don't make comedies like this any more. You know, funny ones.

Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell shine in this magnificent and witty comedy about a divorced couple who agree to collaborate on one more big newspaper story before she gets remarried.  Of course, what woman can resist Cary Grant?  So the more interesting story is, will Hildy remarry, or will she once again fall for Walter?"His Girl Friday" is a classic comedy that cannot be missed!  Look for Cliff Edwards, the voice of Jiminy Cricket, in a small role as Endicott.  I highly recommend "His Girl Friday."  Watch it....you won't be disappointed!

reviews.review_title: Hilarious with abundant clever and witty dialogue!
reviews.content: ***SPOILER INCLUDED***His Girl Friday is the film version of the play The Front Page. Lee Tracy played Hildy Johnson and Osgood Perkins played Walter Burns. In this film, Hildy Johnson was changed to a woman.Don't know why some people think this movie lacks humor. I was chuckling right from the very beginning. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell are Walter Burns and Hildegard "Hildy" Johnson. He's a newspaper editor for the Morning Post and she's a star reporter. They're divorced with no children. I thought their dialogue at the start of the film was so goofy and sarcastic. Despite the funniness in their negative exchanges, one really does get the impression they truly loathe each other. I think it's interesting how some of the earliest movies Cary Grant starred in mirrored his personal life. He found it hard to maintain serious relationships with women, and he didn't have kids from any of his marriages throughout the 1930s and 1940s (his first and only child wasn't born until 1966). Anyway, back to the film - after finding out she's going to marry a dull insurance agent named Bruce Baldwin (Ralph Bellamy) and live in Albany, NY, Walter persuades her to cover one last story. Earl Williams, a bookkeeper who stays to himself, has been convicted of killing a black policeman, and he (Williams) is going to be executed. Walter tells Hildy that she's William's only hope, because her story can prevent him from being executed. The middle of the film was pretty slow, but over time action and hilarity ensues. I know some reviewers said it was annoying how everybody was talking at once, but I thought it was funny. Towards the end when Walter and Hildy were on the phone at the same time, and he started yelling at whoever he was talking to - I lost it and started laughing to the point of tears. There's a lot of name calling and quirky expressions, but it never feels out of place or too random. The only thing I didn't like was how, at the end, she blew off her engagement to Bruce to remarry Walter. So they were trading insults much earlier, but just because they worked together and saved the day, they thought it was a good idea to be a couple again? If only life was that simplistic. Otherwise, I enjoyed His Girl Friday. Where I live we had gotten remnants of Hurricane Ian. It rained for 5 days straight, so this movie was just what I needed to lift my spirits. I highly recommend if you're a fan of old films!

reviews.review_title: One of the Best Screwball Comedies
reviews.content: His Girl Friday is a classic screwball comedy and created an outline for screwballs to come after it. The upbeat and fast-paced tone of this film makes it fun to watch, the amount of words spoken each minute by Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell is amazing to see! It's screwball comedies like His Girl Friday, Bringing Up Baby, and The Philadelphia Story that really define screwball at its best. There are so many things going on at once and it's funny to try and see Hildy manage typing for Walter and talking to Bruce. It's impossible to get bored watching this movie with the amount of things happening in just an hour and a half! I also like the fact that unlike some movies of its time, the main woman in the film is a working woman, really nice to see how she cares about work as well as her love life.

reviews.review_title: Sex Change for 'Hildy' and Rapid Fire, the Step Over Dialogue ratcheting the Laughs higher and more frequent, even!
reviews.content: In the 1928-29 season on Broadway, the Ben Hecht-Charles MacArthur collaboration of THE FRONT PAGE was performed for 276 times. Soon thereafter, Hollywood Beckoned and the movie houses were doing a good business in the filmed version of THE FRONT PAGE (Caddo Company/United Artists, 1931). The film has a quite distinguished pedigree; what with Producer Howard Hughes, Director Lewis Milestone and co-stars Adolph Menjou, Pat O'Brien, Mary Brian, Edward Everett Horton, Mae Clark, George E. Stone and a fine group all turning in excellent and properly cynical, yet humorous performances. This was not to be the only version, though, as Tinsel Town would return to the well frequently.Once again as THE FRONT PAGE (Universal, 1974), the story was filmed; but this time it was the creative team of Director Billy Wilder and "the Odd Couple" of Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau. Additionally, no less than four times (Count 'em folks, 4!); it was adapted for the TV audience. The small screen brought us versions in 1945, 1948, 1949 (As a TV Series, yet!) and in 1970.But the story has much more to it. A reworking of the Premise from being about the Newspaper Racket to the running of a Central American Banana Plantation was the basis for TORRID ZONE (Warner Brothers, 1940); which co-starred James Cagney, Anne Sheridan and Pat O'Brien. This time it was Pat in Walter Burns-type boss role, instead of his being the patsy.A "modern" and updated version transforms the whole scene to the Electronic Media, substituting a Cable News Channel for the "STOP THE PRESSES" Newsprint world in SWITCHING CHANNELS (Tri-Star Pictures, 1988); which Starred Kathleen Turner, Burt Reynolds and Christopher Reeve. This version was Directed by Ted Kocheff. It was different media; but the same old stuff.Now as to Today's Featured Feature Film Festivities, we present, the Star of the Show, Director Howard Hawks' HIS GIRL Friday (Columbia, 1940); which many consider to be the best FRONT PAGE filmed version or adaptation. The story is essentially the same; but there are a couple of major roadblocks thrown in just to make things interesting. Quite simply, they made 'Hildy' a nickname for Hildagard, instead of Hildebrand; then they made the Walter Burns and Hildy Johnson characters into Man & Wife, or more precisely newly divorced Ex-spouses! The rest of the plot is the same. Managing Editor Walter Burns (Mr. Grant) tries to prevent his best reporter, Hildy Johnson (Miss Russell) into staying on to cover the top story of the day. And that story would be the pending execution of an apparently mentally disturbed Cop Killer, one Earl Williams (John Qualen). The seemingly simple premise becomes a most fast moving, breathtakingly paced farce as seen on the Silver Screen.The outstanding performances in the film, and they are many, should be recognized at this time; so then we shall. Beside the Co Stars of Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell we must consider Ralph Bellamy (Bruce Baldwin), Gene Lockhart (Sherriff Peter Hartwell), Frank Orth (Editor Duffy), Helen Mack (Mollie Molloy) and Abner Biberman ("Diamond Louie") all turn in true character performances. Clarence Kolb (the Mayor) and Billy Gilbert (Joe Pettibone, Reprieve Currier) provide the sort of interplay that one would expect from a pair of top-flight Vaudevillians; which, of course, they were! Rounding out this little "Recognition Ceremony" of ours is the group who portrayed "the Gentlemen of the Press", that is the guys camped out in the Press Room at the Jail who await the execution of Earl Williams. That great little group of fast-talking', wise-crackin' men of literature was made up of Ernest Truex (Bensinger), Porter Hall (Murphy), Cliff Edwards (Endicott), Roscoe Karns (McCue) and Regis Toomey (Sanders).

Now, we are into the comedy era of the old times back in the 1940's. This movie's genre is considered a comedy, drama, and romance. This is also still the black and white era. These films are still developing over-time. Like, this film might not have color but it's still an interesting film and the film-eras from back in the day were still being upgraded. For this movie there might not have been color yet for the films but they can still be comedic and funny and have people still want to keep up with the movie. Briefly, this movie is about a man and his ex-wife and he's trying to keep her from remarrying. Overall, the comedies back in the 1940 era are very interesting and they are very funny.

reviews.review_title: Screwball Comedy Masterpiece by Craftsmanship of Hawks
reviews.content: Due to its artistic merit and positive mentality, which must have provided a relief to the American audience during the difficult wartime, the screwball comedy is one of the greatest achievements of the American cinema in its early days. Because the genre tends to carry various aspects of life in one story, making a Screwball Comedy masterpiece requires the craftsmanship of writers and directors. A struggle to balance one's professional life and private one, a positively depicted battle of sexes, an energetic journalism scene and its people--the director Howard Hawks masterfully interweaves these ingredients in His Girl Friday. In addition, the contribution of the celebrated actors can never be appreciated enough. For example, Cary Grant gains the viewers' laughter by his distinguished acting, while nowadays actors in numerous mediocre rom-coms can only do it with situations and deadpan humors.One small drawback is that some side characters, including Bruce Baldwin (the new fiance of Rosalind Russell's Hildy Johnson), Earl Williams (a guy who would be executed), and his girlfriend Molly Malloy, are treated dreadfully, as if they were props.

reviews.review_title: Cute and somewhat funny, but not as great as I thought it would be
reviews.content: Watching `His Girl Friday' I could see why it is widely thought of as a good film and a clear representative of the screwball comedy/fast-talking dame genre, (and a still of Rosalind Russell from this movie is indeed the cover of the book, `Fast Talking Dames') but after it ended I wondered why it was this film that has widely been deemed as the personification of, or even the best of this genre as opposed to its contemporaries.  Remade several times, (and in fact, this was a remake itself) `His Girl Friday' is about Hildy Johnson (Russell), an intrepid reporter who decides to leave the journalist life and marry Bruce (Ralph Bellamy), a boring and bland man who is direct contrast to her conniving and charming ex-husband (and former editor) Walter (Cary Grant).  During the course of the film, Hildy finds herself sucked back into `just one more story' and mayhem ensues.  There is nothing wrong with the acting in the film, it is all quite good; and the script is also fairly funny, if a little dead at times, but I guess my expectations were higher since it was in a fairly high position on the IMDB 250 list.  I'm sure that popularity and exposure is the answer to my question, but I found myself comparing other films from the same time that I thought were much better, (notably, Preston Sturges' `Unfaithfully Yours' which is an absolute scream) and wondered what made this film more highly regarded.  Certainly, star power is another factor, and Cary Grant had it in spades.There isn't a lot that I can specifically criticize the film for, and while it certainly didn't raise my ire up like a lot of films I dislike, it instilled a feeling in me that is almost worse  ambivalence.  I'm glad I saw it finally, but there was nothing exciting about it to deem a repeat viewing anytime in the future.--Shelly

reviews.review_title: A moral center to the maelstrom
reviews.content: By the late 20's Hecht and MacArthur were using Broadway (then Hollywood) to portray Chicago (...and by implication, national) politics in a much more cynical accurate way than audiences had been shown; in this case not only allowing some poor schmoe to be sent to the gallows, but hustling it along to meet an election deadline.Hawks improved on the original by noting a sexual tension between the characters Hildy and Walter and switching the gender of Hildy. I agree with everyone else; this is a stroke of genius. (And I'm very familiar with the original.) While I don't dislike Cary Grant, I'm not in the "He's so classy and talented" crew. But he has some damned funny scenes in this.By the time Grant and Russell are alone in the pressroom making phonecalls and shouting a lot, you may have reached your limit. It's pitched a little too frantic and loud, like the entire movie Arsenic and Old Lace did (also a Grant pic). But it's a small flaw.In comparing this movie to a similar movie concerning a little man, Capra's Meet John Doe is such a treacly, less honest, more conniving take on the topic. You may forget at certain points through all the cynicism that HGF supports a form of activist and advocate journalism. And that even if the leads are externally hard-bitten they are trying to save the life of an innocent man; the moral center of the movie.There are still rubes who believe that a president is exactly whom he presents himself to be. This movie shows that they're only 90 years behind the times.

one of that films who seduce. this its theirs mission and purpose and virtue. a love story who seems have the best illustration in the duel between Hepburn and Tracey. and who has a specific flavor in this case because it reminds the old war love-hate in media industry but, in same measure, because Carey Grant is absolutely charming.and Rosalind Russel is his the perfect partner. and this is the most important detail. and the motif for see, again, one of the many old comedies, predictable, lovely and, in strange way, unique. a film who preserves the joy to discover old silhouettes of Hollywood from the best angle. so, a must see.

reviews.review_title: The first dissapointing film with Cary Grant
reviews.content: Grant himself is great as usual, but the film is far away from being brilliant. This is the first Cary Grant's film which I rated lower than 8/10I don't understand why is it considered so important and funny. This fast pace isn't funny but rather irritating. Only a few times I smiled or appreciated the jokes. My idea of a great picture is not only decent dialogues (which this film doesn't have either), but also a good story, camera work, directing. His Girl Friday doesn't have a single one of them. Directing is pretty usual, the story is cockeyed. Only actors did a really good job, especially the leading ones. Maybe I just don't like these 30's - 50's films about nothing and with lots of babble and no sense and good story at all, but I give this film only 6/10 for good actors' performances and some funny moments.

reviews.review_title: Good work, maybe source material a problem
reviews.content: This was a pretty good film, but I did not find it as awesome as apparently most people did. Cary Grant was in fine form, and I was impressed with Rosalind Russell. I haven't seen much of her earlier work, and always thought of her as the Mother Superior in "The Trouble With Angels". She was quite beautiful here, and played her role with the feistiness it required. But the whole thing left me a bit cold, and not for the reasons mentioned by others (overrunning dialog, insensitive plot elements like suicide and execution, politically incorrect references to black folks). Interestingly, I felt the same way when I saw Billy Wilder's version with Jack Lemmon and Walter Matheau. With the cast and directors of both films among my favorites, I'm at a bit of a loss as to why I didn't care all that much for these films. I suppose that I simply wouldn't have cared for the original play, and all dissatisfaction stems from that

reviews.review_title: One of the most annoying movies I have ever seen.
reviews.content: I thought that people who loved good cinema would all have similar tastes, boy was I wrong.  I had to sit through this P.O.S. in my film class.  If I hadn't been in class I would have turned it off after the first 20 minutes (and a movie has to be REALLY bad to make me do that).  I kept waiting for the characters to go somewhere or do something.  I can watch David Lynch movies about nothing and enjoy them, but this was just aweful.  After about an hour I realized that the whole movie was going to be the same.  After the movie was over I realized that I had lost 2 hours of my life that I can never get back.  As far as comedies go I put it right up there with Caddyshack 2... aweful. No good music, no good cinematography, no characters that I like or care about(mean characters that put an innocent man in jail), and not a single funny moment.To each their own!

I think there are three versions of this play kicking around out there and this one is the best, not to mention the fastest.The director, Howard Hawks, was always good at light comedy, improvising gags on the spot and taking all sorts of liberties with the script. Sometimes the plot got lost along the way ("The Big Sleep") but he was always a superb story teller.Hildy Johnson, Rosalind Russell, is an ace reporter about to marry a dull insurance salesman, Ralph Bellamy, but her editor wants to keep her on the paper. Cary Grant couldn't have been a better choice for the role of Walter Burns, Hildy Johnson's editor. He's handsome and roguish and lies with every breath he takes.Hawks rewrote the play. In the original, Hildy was a man but Hawks, who never quite got his gender roles straight, heard a talk-through and decided it would be more interesting if Hildy were a woman. And that enabled the writers to introduce the jealousy element, which wouldn't have fit the original story unless we're talking homoeroticism.I felt kind of sorry for Ralph Bellamy's character. Even his name -- Bruce Baldwin -- sounds like the noise a foot might make when it's being pulled from sludge. The poor guy is earnest, sincere, highly principled, and lives with his mother in Albany. He's the kind of man that every woman in the 1930s wanted to build a home with -- a beastly impulse in itself -- only they'd have to get rid of mother first. Ground glass in the Pablum perhaps.That mother is a real pain in the neck too. She's supposed to accompany them on the overnight train to Albany and travel with them on their honeymoon. Burns traps the feisty old lady into some contretemps and tells his goon, Louie, "Take her down to Polack Mike's and tell the cops she was plastered," or something like that.Try putting a line like that into a politically correct movie today. Polack Mike's. Notwithstanding the fact that the Polish word for Polish people is "polaki." The movie rises into the surreal once in a while. The assembled reporters, when they're not playing poker in the press room, speak in headlines. They call their editors with stories that can't possibly be printed. If additional guards will be placed around the scaffold during Earl Williams' hanging, the lead is "Sheriff just adds new family members to city payroll." Roger Ebert, a Chicago newsman himself, took some pleasure in seeing how much things had changed since the 1920s, but the change was to be expected. The eternal verities aren't very eternal when you get right down to it. When I was a kid, every car looked like it had been made in 1939, the mass was said in Latin, and you could supposedly look up girls' dresses by covertly glancing at their patent leather shoes. Now -- it's all changed. And where did it go? (Sob.) Kleenex, please. Thank you.What an enjoyable and funny movie this is. Oh, it creaks at the joints, but that's to be expected because it's so old. It's like Cary Grant talking Ralph Bellamy into writing out Grant's insurance policy with Rosalind Russel as the beneficiary. Bellamy objects a bit because he wants to provide for her all by himself. But what if he can't? "Can't you just imagine Hildy when you're gone? Sitting on the porch swing? Old lace and lavender?" Bellamy says dreamily, "Yes, I can." Grant stands back and snaps, "She's OOOOLD, isn't she!" I can't stop laughing at the irreverence.

To be upfront I didn't really enjoy this film. Although I understood it's faced paced tone was supposed to reflect the speed pf that eras news room, it seemed to move to fast to enjoy what little comedy that was displayed. The scheming done by the head reporter and his lackey were more frustrating to watch then comical and most of the time I just ended up feeling sorry for the woman reporter and her fiancé. Between the corruption of the media and the fact that the leading woman being tricked into a life she wanted to give up I just didn't feel anything for the characters and the story taking place. I'm sure that this film is a masterpiece to some people but it just wasn't my cup of tea.

reviews.review_title: The Front Page Turns for Rosalind Russell
reviews.content: New York metropolitan area reporter Rosalind Russell (as Hildegard "Hildy" Johnson) arrives in the bustling office of "The Morning Post" to tell ex-husband and editor Cary Grant (as Walter Burns) she's leaving the business to marry insurance salesman Ralph Bellamy (as Bruce Baldwin). The couple plans to move up to the state capitol of Albany, where Ms. Russell wants to keep house and have Mr. Bellamy's children. Russell rejects Mr. Grant's offer to re-marry and remain a reporter. Sensing Russell really loves him and wants to continue her assignments, Grant maneuvers to have her cover the recent shooting of a "colored" policeman, by troubled bookkeeper John Qualen (as Earl Williams)...This re-make of Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur's "The Front Page" most notably swaps the gender of the roles played by Russell and Bellamy, which gives everything a lift. Russell plays a strong "Hildy" but succumbs to some stereotypes by the end; still, we believe she will manage to asset herself in the future. The pace is breakneck and the script fast, with overlapping dialogue spilling out of the newsroom. Double-takes include the "pickaninny" story (carried over from the original) and the way Bellamy's character is described by Grant, "He looks like that fellow in the movies - Ralph Bellamy." Director Howard Hawks knows when to leave a take alone, and walk-ons like Billy Gilbert are great.******** His Girl Friday (1/11/40) Howard Hawks ~ Rosalind Russell, Cary Grant, Ralph Bellamy, John Qualen

An impeccable screwball comedy; fast-paced, witty and excellent rapid-fire dialogue. Hildy(Rosalind Russell)is an ace reporter that has divorced her ex-husband editor Walter Burns(Cary Grant)and he tries to put her back on the job to help the tabloid free a condemned man(John Qualen)from the long arm or the law. Hildy has only returned to the office to announce her whirlwind engagement to an insurance salesman(Ralph Bellamy). Burns does his best to convince Hildy to write a front-page story about the innocent man who is about to hang. Walter doesn't hide the fact he wants his ex-wife back in his arms...and oh yes, back on her old job.Director Howard Hawks is faultless in his version of the 1931 play "The Front Page". Its a hilarious slap-stick battle of the sexes. The supporting cast includes: Regis Toomey, Porter Hall, Helen Mack, Frank Jenks and Gene Lockhart.

Howard Hawks, as Pauline Kael claims, may not have invented rapid crossfire dialogue (his source material, the play `The Front Page' probably accounts for that and screwball comedies like `It Happened One Night' can also be cited) but he was a master of it and `His Girl Friday' pins its humor on cynical wit delivered with speed. Cary Grant is absolutely charming as newspaper editor Walter Burns, a rogue with tunnel vision focused only on scooping the competition. With an execution about to take place, he calls upon his ace reporter, Hildy Johnson (a smooth but vulnerable Rosalind Russell), who just happens to be Burns' ex-wife and who is planning to retire and settle down with creampuff insurance agent Bruce Baldwin (the ever-likable Ralph Bellamy). The action shows its stage roots, confined mostly to several indoor sets and the pace flags a bit toward the end but overall the film is a sharp undertaking, a sardonic comedy with dark currents of Depression-era despair embedded in it.

reviews.review_title: A real rarity - a comedy that's actually funny!
reviews.content: There really aren't any good comedies around at the moment.  Within the past five years or so, there have been only two that have really stood out; There's Something About Mary, and The Castle.  If you don't like Jim Carrey, lazy spoofs, or the gross-out 80s teen revival, you're not going to find many laughs in the cinema.There seems to be an increasing reliance on cross-genre films, that describe themselves as comedy-drama to excuse their lack of laughs.  One good joke every half hour is the usual average, and the TV sitcom has overtaken cinema as the most reliable joke-teller.  It's frustrating that there are a few laughs every minute in a 22 minute episode of Seinfeld or Roseanne, but a movie sets its sights so low that you're lucky to find one memorable line in the whole thing.It's refreshing, then, to go back to when comedies were actually funny, and funny for their intelligent dialogue as opposed to second rate sarcasm, and funny for their inventive slapstick as opposed to someone just slipping on a puddle of vomit and falling on his arse.  The speed and intelligence of His Girl Friday puts modern comedies to shame.Every Cary Grant movie has charm just from his being cast, and he is matched here by Rosalind Russell.  They combine to bring one of the funniest partnerships in film, and their extraordinary chemistry lends credibility to the obvious ending.  It's predictability comes not from being such a clichéd plot device, but from their attraction being obvious and genuine from the outset.  The venomous insults from Russell and the devious flirting from Grant are just perfect.The pace of the film is mentioned in every review, and it has to be mentioned again here.  It's simply breathtaking, and shows supreme confidence in getting more jokes out in one scene than most movies manage in their entire running time.  There are moments when it gets frustrating because laughter from one joke drowns out the next, and without the rewind button half the script would go unheard.  The quality and concentration of the jokes guarantee that this is one to watch over and over.Beyond the manic pace and endless one-liners, there are serious points that give the film a greater depth.  It has much to say about career politicians, who care only for their ambitions, and the role of the press, who care only about their story.  There is a surprising cynicism that translates perfectly to a modern audience, and Grant's idea that `divorce doesn't mean anything nowadays' is wonderfully cutting and more relevant now than back then.  It is equally modern in its presentation of Russell, who is acknowledged as the best of the reporters.  Surprising for a film of such age, her character is never patronised, and never treated as a gimmick.  Indeed, the only things that date it at all are the few references to Hitler and the `European War'.It's hard to write a review that does justice to such a great comedy without quoting half of it, but the jokes deserve to be seen in context and delivered by the cast itself.  But I have to mention the great in-jokes, of Cary Grant describing Russell's fiancé as looking `like that actor Ralph Bellamy', and then making a quick reference to Archie Leach.His Girl Friday is one of the funniest, fastest comedies ever made, and when you next come back from the cinema in a bad mood after seeing the latest non-comedy, stop by a video store and rent this to remind yourself that some films can actually make you laugh.

reviews.review_title: As fast, furious and screwball as they come...
reviews.content: Howard Hawks directs this fast-paced screwball comedy at a such a brisk, breath-taking pace that it's a wonder the actors related so intimately to all the dialog. But they do--and ROSALIND RUSSELL, CARY GRANT and RALPH BELLAMY are about as perfectly cast as they ever have been in this sort of romp.The plot has Grant doing everything within his power to keep Russell on his newspaper as his top reporter and also everything he can to break up the romance between Bellamy and Russell when he finds out she's about to marry the screen's favorite "other man". At one point in the screenplay, he tells a blonde moll to look for the man in the taxicab who looks like that movie actor--you know, Ralph Bellamy. Another quip has him bringing up the name of Archibald Leach, another inside joke for those in the know.Russell is the mistress of fast dialog and has a role that is way over the top, a parody of a fast-talking newspaper woman if ever there was one. She, Grant and Bellamy have a delicious scene early in the film where Grant is treating them to lunch after she breaks the news of her engagement. The interaction between these three stars as they prepare to lunch together is the ultimate in timing and comic interplay between three pros.As screwball comedies go, this is one of the best. The overlapping dialog may be a bit too much at times, but still the concept works because of the impeccable acting credentials of the entire cast.Well worth watching for the performances alone. Cary and Roz and Ralph are at their comic peak.

"His Girl Friday" was a fast-talking comedy with some good laughs and a solid script.It stars Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell. Russell plays Hildy Johnson, a reporter who quit the biz and was set to marry an insurance salesman and move to Albany. Her last bit of business at her old place of employment was to inform her ex-boss/ex-husband, Walter Burns (Cary Grant), that she was moving on. Walter, ever the hustler and scheister, came up with one scheme after another to lure Hildy back into the newspaper business. It was a back and forth affair and a battle of wills and wits between Hildy and Walter to see who would win. Would Hildy stick to her guns and move on with her life, or would she fall prey to Walter's tricks and jump back into the newspaper racket?

To be honest, I expected this movie to be different from how it was. The beginning started out well, I was interesting and I was following it. Then it went into another direction entirely. Suddenly there were a dozen characters and I could barely keep up with names or who was who. The entire movie seemed to just be people shouting over the top of everyone else, so I could barely understand information and sort it out in my mind. It probably didn't help anything that even though I was in a quiet area with my volume up, the sound in the copy of the movie I saw was very low. Another thing was the way jokes were peppered into the conversation, but the characters were speaking a mile a minute. So really, I was only able to get the real gist of the plot.

I didn't expect to find this movie funny due to my lack of experience with old comedies. I felt that the references and jokes will slip me by. Yet, His Girl Friday remarkably holds up. Holding the record for the fastest dialogue in a movie ever, it blazes through scenarios, jokes and quips. Absurd scenarios and dynamic banters all serve the make this movie feel over the top. The dynamic between the two main character's was witty and subtle. The story is fine.It's a fun movie and I certainly hope we can see a comeback for screwball in our modern comedy movies.

reviews.review_title: Fast-Paced Comedy That Rarely Falls Flat
reviews.content: Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell star opposite each other in the classic Howard Hawks 1940 comedy 'His Girl Friday'. This film is remarkable for it's pace and snappy dialogue.Hildy Johnson (Rosalind Russell,in a superb performance) is an ace news reporter preparing for her second marriage. She loves her job, but her sweet yet boring insurance salesman fiancé Bruce (Ralph Bellamy) would prefer her to be a housewife, not a career woman. Hildy warms to the idea, and goes to the office to tell her editor Walter Burns (Cary Grant, great as usual)she's through with the newspaper game and ready for the quieter side of life. Trouble is, Walter hates the thought of losing his star reporter and ex-wife to another man and cooks up a series of schemes to get Bruce out of the picture and Hildy to stay on the job! He's still in love with her of course, and convinces her to cover one last big story about murderer Earl Williams, who is on death row. Will he get her back or will Hildy's last hurrah satisfy her? Poor Ralph Bellamy. In both this and 'The Awful Truth' he has to play the poor sap to the witty, urbane Grant. Ros Russell matches Grant with every line, and it is amazing how fast she could deliver her lines. Grant was the undisputed king of comedy and fast-pacing, yet Ros almost tops him in this one! They are marvellous together, and ooze sophistication. The funniest moments in this film definitely come from the Grant-Russell teaming, and Grant's series of pranks to get rid of Bellamy. There is rarely a gag that fails to deliver. My only query about the film is, surprisingly, the dialogue. There's nothing wrong with it, it's just delivered so fast that some words are missed completely in the speed of it all.'His Girl Friday' is also a great satire of the newspaper industry and the length reporters will go to to cover a story. Catch the inside jokes about Ralph Bellamy and 'Archie Leach'- pure wit and cheek! 9/10.

His Girl Friday (1940): Dir: Howard Hawks / Cast: Rosalind Russell, Cary Grant, Ralph Bellamy, Gene Lockhart, John Qualen: Amusing screwball comedy about the lifestyles we cannot pull ourselves away from. "His" points at either a newspaper tycoon played by Cary Grant or an insurance agent played by Ralph Bellamy with Rosalind Russell as Friday, Grant's ex-wife torn between the two. Hilarious situations follow where Grant creates obstacles that prevent the couple from making their train. Russell realizes that grant is the reason her fiancée has been arrested three times but she cannot turn down a big story of a cop shooting and a suspect on death row. Directed by Howard Hawks as a worthy followup to his hilarious Bringing Up Baby. The production is too stagy and the conclusion is somewhat sour when figuring one factor tampers with the affairs of another. Russell is terrific as a woman wanting to settle down yet motivated by her career. Grant is on target with fast talk and faster thinking. Bellamy is a great foil, bewildered as to the predicaments he is thrust within. Gene Lockhart plays an airhead Sheriff. John Qualen plays a convict up for murder and Friday is doing one last story on this individual. Qualen eventually escapes but turns up during the comedic climax. It regards direction and knowing oneself both personally and professionally. Not that there are any professionals here. Score: 6 / 10

Howard Hawks directed this rapid-fire comedy that sees Cary Grant playing Chicago newspaper editor Walter Burns, who is desperately trying to prevent his ex-wife and ace reporter Hildy Johnson(played by Rosalind Russell) from marrying an insurance salesman(played by Ralph Bellamy). There is a big story involving an impending execution going on, and Walter wants Hildy to cover it, which makes a most convenient excuse to stop them getting married! Of course, complications ensue when the man about to be executed escapes... Well acted and witty film is reasonably funny, but does come close to being obnoxious at times, but lead characters are at least tolerable, and film breathlessly paced.

reviews.review_title: A solid comedy and a terrific movie.
reviews.content: A very pleasant surprise (and never boring), "His Girl Friday" is a movie with such a crackling script that you kinda feel dizzy at the end after keeping up with the lightning-quick dialogue. This is my first Cary Grant movie (never too late to start, right?), and his leading man hair and dimpled chin star power ably support his foray into such a screwball comedy. His character is so amoral that the guy's just ... he's damn likable. But the real star of this movie (at least, to me) is Rosalind Russell. I know nothing of the play on which this is based, but I wouldn't be surprised if her character was originally a man. She trades jabs with the other newsboys like a fellow man. But this is hardly a complaint; it makes Russell and her character a thrill to watch. She's the fulcrum on which the story pivots and it's heartening to see her go toe-to-toe with any other male character. Poor Ralph Bellamy's naive character has to play straight-man to the others' chicanery, but he's at least the beneficiary of one of the movie's best lines (and a bit of meta humor that directly references himself as an actor). What's really surprising is just how many laughs come from the supporting players. A fine movie, at that.8/10

When people tell me that classical Hollywood films do not appeal to them, I understand it. Except for Citizen Kane, that is. It's hard to argue in any case with that film. But if someone says "I don't like Casablanca," I can understand that. Not that I don't like Casablanca. I like it quite a lot. It's just that, well, as much as I like Ingrid Bergman and Humphrey Bogart, I just don't think that their skills as actors are very high (well, Bergman's good, while I would pick any number of actresses from foreign films or silent films or more modern films). This is because I do not think true acting, at least for the American talkies, came about until the likes of James Dean and Marlon Brando. Acting before seems only to have been born from the style of acting you see in the theater. I have never been a huge fan of the theater because of this same reason. Actors act only with their voices. They have to get what they are saying heard, so nothing ever sounds sincere. There are so few silent moments.His Girl Friday is a great example of this. There is not a second where people aren't talking a mile a minute. Even when the dialogue is great, it starts to grate on your patience. But this is just a small criticism of mine. Although I would completely sympathize with someone disliking this film, I liked it a lot. Even if the dialogue does grate, it is still great. And the actors, even if they do act as if they're on a stage and not as if they were human beings, are very good. Cary Grant is always great to watch. His abilities are effortless. I could never imagine him in a serious role (I'm sure he had to have had a few; my only other Cary Grant experiences are two of his Hitchcock films: To Catch a Thief and North By Northwest). He's a lot like Bogart, and any number of other stars (as opposed to actors), whose persona is so fun that we go along with him wherever he goes. Rosalind Russel is an actress I've never seen before. If I ever do, I won't be able to see much beyond the persona she establishes as Hildy Johnson. She may have been a very popular actress, for all I know, but even if this were her first film, she holds her own with Grant. The supporting character actors, especially the other newsmen, the gangster, the sheriff, the mayor, etc, are all very good. My only other complaint is that the few dramatic moments in the film tend to work against the overall comedic mood of the picture. The entire execution part of the plot seems almost as if it is from another movie. And especially the suicide attempt of Molly Malloy (what a terrible name, by the way) hurts the film. In fact, the rest of the movie is so good, that it almost cancels out these creaks. Almost. 8/10.

I have never seen "The Front Page", the stage play on which "His Girl Friday" was based, or either of the two filmed versions of it from 1931 and 1974. I understand, however, that in those versions of the story the character of Hildy Johnson was male, and that when Howard Hawks made this version he originally intended to follow the original play in this respect. He eventually, however, changed his mind and made Hildy female. (At this period a "girl Friday" was a junior female office assistant; the application of the term to Hildy, an experienced journalist, is presumably ironic).Like many of the screwball comedies of this period, this one is a "comedy of remarriage". (In the same year, 1940, Cary Grant made two other films of this type, "My Favourite Wife" and "The Philadelphia Story"). The normal plot line is that the male and female leads are a divorced or separated couple who end up rediscovering their love for one another, and the attraction of this sort of story for filmmakers was that it allowed them to deal with the theme of divorce, then considered very daring and sophisticated, while providing a happy ending which would please even the most hardened moralist by showing the triumph of conjugal love. (Although the heyday of comedies of remarriage was in the thirties and forties, they have never gone away; "Bird on a Wire" and "Sweet Home Alabama" are two more recent examples).Grant here stars as Walter Burns, a newspaper editor. Hildy (in this version it's short for Hildegard) is not only his former star reporter but also his former wife. Their marriage and their business relationship have now come to an end and Hildy intends to settle down to a quiet life of domesticity with her new fiancé Bruce Baldwin, a rather dull (and none too intelligent) insurance salesman. Walter, however, asks Hildy to cover one last story for him, the execution of convicted murderer Earl Williams, and she accepts, less as a favour to her ex-husband than because she wants to help save the life of a man she believes to be innocent. Which leads to many further complications, including the inevitable discovery that Walter and Hildy are still in love with one another.Although "His Girl Friday" is primarily a romantic comedy, it does contain some satirical barbs aimed at the American newspaper industry; Hildy's idealism and concern for accuracy set her apart from most of her colleagues in the press room, who are only concerned with landing a spectacular scoop which may or may not bear any relation to the truth. On a more serious level the film also has some things to say about the death penalty and about political interference in the judicial process; the city's corrupt mayor and sheriff are anxious, for political reasons, to see Williams executed so do all they can to bring this about, even trying to bribe the messenger bringing a reprieve from the governor to go away.The film is noted for its quick- fire dialogue, particularly in the "battle of the sexes" exchanges between Walter and Hildy. It manages to pack a large amount of verbal material into a relatively short running time. One notable innovation is the use of overlapping dialogue with one character speaking before another finishes. (This technique has also been used by a number of more recent directors, such as Robert Aldrich). This development not only has the effect of making conversations sound more realistic, it also adds a greater sense of pace and rapid movement.The film also plays games with a well-worn movie convention, the convention that nobody ever notices the resemblance between a fictional character and the actor playing that character. Normally all films starring (for example) Cary Grant take place in a parallel universe in which the actor Cary Grant does not exist. Here, however, Walter describes Baldwin by saying "He looks like that fellow in the movies, you know...Ralph Bellamy!" Bellamy was, of course, the actor playing Baldwin. (This line was, apparently, an ad lib on Grant's part, but the director Howard Hawks liked it and allowed it to remain). Another film which plays a similar game is the more recent "Ocean's Twelve" in which Julia Roberts plays a character who is pretending to be Julia Roberts "because everyone says I look like her".Cary Grant had a natural gift for screwball comedy which made him the obvious choice to play Walter; Hawks had two years earlier directed him in another famous screwball, "Bringing Up Baby". Rosalind Russell, however, was not the first choice to play Hildy; that was Carole Lombard, but the studio could not afford her. Nor was she the second choice; that was Katharine Hepburn, Grant's co-star in "Bringing up Baby" and "The Philadelphia Story", but she turned the part down, as did several other actresses. Russell, however, makes the part so completely her own that it is difficult to imagine anyone else in the role, and combines well with Grant in a two-person comedy team. (I was not previously particularly familiar with Russell's work, except as the stage mother from hell in "Gypsy", so I was interested to see another side to her).I would not rank "His Girl Friday" quite as highly as "The Philadelphia Story", one of the best comedies of the period, but it is certainly better than "My Favourite Wife", a dated, sentimental film which today comes across as more cornball than screwball. It is a fast-moving, witty comedy which still stands up well today. 8/10

This mile-a-minute screwball comedy focuses upon an ex-reporter who, despite her best efforts, finds herself drawn back into the newspaper game both by her scheming ex-husband and, when a life-or-death story rears its head, her own, seemingly insatiable curiosity. 'His Girl Friday (1940)' is stuffed with witty, fast-paced dialogue that makes Aaron Sorkin's stuff seem woefully slow; it's often hard to keep up with. However, it's also remarkably entertaining. It's funny throughout and it even features a fairly well-rounded plot, which unfolds essentially in tandem with the character sparring that serves as the main event. There's more to it than you might expect and Rosalind Russell makes an excellent leading lady who's more than capable of keeping up with Cary Grant. It's a really enjoyable affair. 7/10

a special version of Front Page. seductive, inspired and different. not only for the option for Rosalind Russell - Cary Grant as lead couple but for the different manner to give new nuances to an old play. it has all ingredients of a romance -commedy from 1940. but it is not reduced to that. it is different by the classic war between she and he and this is the merit of a good director who explores each level of art of actors. and, sure, the manner to give to story brilliance and a kind of charm. the star is Rosalind Russell and her clever performance is a good opportunity to support the usual manner to create his character by Cary Grant. a nice film who remember the spirit and science of sparkles of a period who was so far by the recipes of our time.

reviews.review_title: my head is going to explode!!!!!!!
reviews.content: Imagine watching a movie where every character is portrayed by John Moschitta the motor mouthed micro machines guy after he's snorted a mountain of coke. that should give you an idea of what watching this movie feels like. And it's too bad, because slowed down maybe 10% or 15% it might be a lot easier to digest and more of the jokes would get a chance to hit their mark. Underneath the speed reading of the script is an intelligent movie that mocks the pretensions of journalists, deflates the pomp of politicians, and still finds time to lance the boil of early girl power aggro feminism. the but of these jokes is as applicable to early 21st century american life as it is to mid 20th century life. The actors have done a magnificent job of being able to remember and recite long trains of complex rapid fire dialogue combined with precise stage directions necessary for the early years of complex sound recording. The unfortunate part is that while sometimes it's a good thing for jokes to come fast and furious, other times it's good just to sit back and let a joke sink in slowly. the director in his zeal to pack as much in to 90 minutes as possible does not grasp comic timing so well. an otherwise great movie suffers for it.

"A classic screwball comedy at its goofiest, awash with snappy exchanges, overlapped dialogue (an experimental innovation that requires more technical finesse at then) and a deprecating side-eye on the fourth estate. HIS GIRL FRIDAY is at its best when Grant and Russell engage with their high-octane, rapid-fire battle of sparring and banters. Grant masks Walter's unscrupulousness with a deceptive insouciance and chumminess, he is not above to lie blatantly in front of an accusation of kidnap, which we all know it is true, and occasionally he seems more emotive with the telephone in his hand than with Russell, his unbowed sparring partner, who also carries off an air of gameness to fight Hildy's corner in earnest and with copacetic facility."read my full review on my blog: Cinema Omnivore, thanks.

There's so much fast-talking dialogue in this brilliant Howard Hawks movie that you almost need two sets of ears to keep up. There's plenty of plot too though as Hawks mixes his mastery of the screwball comedy with an escaped prisoner, newspaper machinations, political corruption and of course, a twisted, barbed love story into one heady, breathless mix.The film is famous for its overlapping dialogue and even when it's not it's delivered lightning fast demanding perfect timing from its lead actors in the main. Enter Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell as editor and top reporter, ex-husband and wife and on-going sparring partners, both happily on top form as they go at each other hammer and tongs before the inevitable conclusion is reached at the end of the film.Only when the humour takes in the character of the portly court messenger delivering the governor's pardon does the humour become weak and forced, otherwise it's pacey, racy and at times risqué especially when Grant is in full-flow as only he can. I loved the insertion of the in-joke on Ralph Bellamy and wonder if it was an improvisation which the director liked and kept in. I also picked up on references to a number of topical subjects such as the European War the US hadn't yet entered and the gangster-crime of the day, highlighted when Grant in a phone call to his paper rejects potential lead stories one-by- one, to make way for Hildy's scoop covering the condemned prisoner's break-out.Set-bound as it is, perhaps unwittingly betraying its theatrical originals, Hawks' fast-moving direction ensures the viewer's attention is held from start to finish and in Grant and Russell, he had the perfect actors to make his film fly.This is classic Golden Age Hollywood film-making of the top-rank and although other versions of this story have been made down the years, this has to be the definitive version, I'd wager.

reviews.review_title: Great Gem of a Classic Film
reviews.content: This entire cast gave a great performance in this film which was directed by Howard Hawks who told his actors to improvise their lines whenever possible. Walter Burns, ( Cary Grant) plays the role of a newspaper man who still loves his ex-wife Hildy Johnson, (Rosalind Russell, however, Hildy tells Walter that she is going to marry another man named Bruce Baldwin, (Ralph Bellamy) and she wants to quit the newspaper business and settle down and have babies. Walter contrives all kinds of situations in order to get his wife back and he starts to cause all kinds of problems with Bruce in order to break up their relationship with his ex-wife. This is a very fast paced film with quick lines and plenty of excitement. Enjoy.

reviews.review_title: Not bad, but needed more of the relationship/love triangle
reviews.content:
Pros
Rosalind Russell turns in a great performance and portrays a strong newspaper reporter, better than the male reporters. She's also someone who has taken control of her life, seeing through the manipulations of her ex-husband and ex-boss, Cary Grant. Her lines like "you're wonderful, in a loathsome sort of way" are fantastic.There are some very cute moments between Grant and Russell as he needles her about her new fiancée (Ralph Bellamy), and of course immediately begins to try undermining them. The scenes early on grab you, with fast, sharp dialog, Russell throwing her purse at Grant in his office, and the two playing cat and mouse with their eyes and gestures at lunch with Bellamy. I loved these parts.Cons
There is not enough of the relationship/banter/love triangle. The film is at its best early on, but when it begins focusing on the convicted killer, the plot line that gives Russell the lure to return to reporting, it bogs down and loses my interest.Fans of zany, frenetic, screwball movies will like this film, but at some point everyone just seems to be shouting at one another, and there just isn't enough balance in it for me.It's somewhat incidental, but I wasn't a fan of the premise that the white killer was convicted and unfairly sentenced because he had killed a black policeman, as if this and not the reverse was (and is) the problem in America, and the heaviness of the satire on the free press.

Howard Hawks made the perfect screen comedy with 1940's "His Girl Friday", as it re-tells the tale told on stage and screen as "The Front Page". Walter Burns is a manipulative, yet charming newspaper man with an important story about to explode about an innocent man on the eve of execution. Walter's sharp-tongued and highly independent ex-wife, Hildy Johnson, has since quit the news business, but has dropped by to let him know she is remarrying the following day. The clock is ticking on the innocent man's life, as well as Walter's presumed second chance with Hildy, so what are a couple of fine talents like Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell to do but spew out their inspired and quotable dialogue out twice as fast. Equally fast-paced is the story, and the steadily building screwball chaos. This one epitomizes the title 'classic'.

Hildy Johnson (Rosalind Russell) marches into the newsroom to tell her ex-husband Walter Burns (Cary Grant) that she is quitting the paper and marrying a reliable, earnest, mild-mannered and relatively dull insurance salesman, Bruce (Ralph Bellamy) and moving to Albany to live a saner life. Walter still loves her and does not want to lose his best reporter, so he sets out to undermine her decision and keep her on staff.The real star of this film is the writing. Throughout most of His Girl Friday the dialogue moves along at breakneck page. Take a look at the first scene in Walter's office, where the ex-spouses are bantering back and forth. You have to wonder how long it took to get that one film. Great work by the two actors to remember those lines and spit them out so quickly while retaining the intent of the lines.This is a multi-layered comedy. Where most comedies employ only one or two elements of comedy, HGF layers many elements and achieves success with each. Note the use of physical comedy (as when Walter lifts his shorter minion high enough to look through the glass into his office). The script is filled with inside jokes, which are more fun if left to the viewer to discover. The dialogue moves so quickly that you might miss some of the wordplay, but even on first viewing you can pick up more than enough to dazzle. A running gag is the dueling phone conversations, displays of great timing and, probably, much rehearsal. Speaking of timing, certain scenes are classic farce.Through all the fun and games, HGF also manages to comment on some serious issues. The politicians and the journalists sometimes battle, but they both are shown to be unscrupulous and unconcerned with truth. Another reviewer called HGF a "tribute to journalists", but I say it excoriates the trade--depicted in this film as exponents of yellow journalism.A reviewer also said that it is difficult to imagine anyone else playing the leads in this film. I often feel that way about a film, but not in this case. When you read about all the actors who turned down the roles or who were passed over, I can imagine most of them playing these parts. Clark Gable as Walter? Absolutely. Ginger Rogers or Irene Dunn or Jean Arthur as Hildy? Sure. The writing is so good that it rises above the actors who inhabit these roles. That is not to say that I didn't appreciate Rosalind Russel's ability to play a believable reporter who hangs out with and competes with the boys. I like the way she uses her ambling walk when Hildy is in her reporter mode. And Cary Grant really captures the shrewdness of Walter--a man who can change strategies or personalities on a dime. He is the real salesman, not Bruce. In the scene were he treats Hildy and Bruce to lunch, try to imagine Grouch Marx in the role of Walter. The writing is so good, it can mold itself to the comedy stylings of many actors.

It's always interesting to watch classic films that have a very different tone and feel to anything that comes out in today's world. His Girl Friday is very much a screwball comedy, and that genre in itself is a product of its time. It still holds up 70 some odd years later, but films just aren't made this way anymore. It's a fast talking and dialogue driven film about a man who is willing to do whatever it takes to keep his ex-wife and former reporter from marrying an insurance man.Cary Grant plays Walter Burns, the editor of the Morning Post., while Rosalind Russell plays his ex-wife and reporter Hildegard 'Hildy' Johnson. It's based on a play, but Howard Hawks, the director, made one bold but brilliant move by switching the sex of the Hildy character. I'm not sure how the play was written, but the dynamic between Hildy and Walter creates not only immensely funny moments, but also a relationship you root for in a film. Normally, it's not easy to root for a character who wishes to break up a soon- to-be marriage, but Grant brought a great sense vulnerability that proved to make it easier to feel for his character. It doesn't hurt that Cary Grant is one of the most charismatic actors of all time. What I found most impressive wasn't the acting or the notably funny script, it was the direction of Howard Hawks. I had seen a few of his films in the past including The Big Sleep and one of my favorite films of all time, Bringing up Baby, but it was his direction here that caught my attention the most. It's very difficult to keep an audience's attention without any real action or a ton of physical comedy like his other films, but Hawks uses these dialogue driven scenes in a way that doesn't feel overwhelming, instead, it proved to be very entertaining. I understand that the invention multi- track recording wasn't developed yet, so he told the sound mixing crew to turn the overhead microphones on and off throughout the film to create the final product. It's that dedication and attention to detail that makes Hawks one of the most celebrated filmmakers of all time.As I said before, this film is a product of its time in the way it's made. If you look at the editing for films that come out today, it's smoother and the cuts aren't usually very noticeable. In His Girl Friday, you can tell that the technology wasn't available for them to make each cut appear as seamless as they should be. It doesn't necessarily dampen the film's greatness, it's just a way of telling when it was made. In comparison to other comedies close to its release, such as The Philadelphia Story, another one of Grant's remarriage films, I think His Girl Friday has a much lighter tone. The sub- genre of screwball comedies known as the 'comedy of remarriage' has turned out some great entries like Holiday and Bringing up Baby. The ladder being far more like a Chaplin comedy than this film was in its humor. But His Girl Friday proves to be lighter, wittier, and probably aesthetically more important for its significance historically.The narrative focuses a lot on getting a 'scoop' as most of its main characters are writers of some sort. While newspapers are nowhere near as popular as they were during that time, I think the days of getting 'scoops' have returned. Whether it's breaking the latest in a political race, what the Kardashians have been up to, or dropping the latest scoop on the next superhero movie, the media is still obsessed with being first at something, except now it's on social media. So in a way, that's an argument against that His Girl Friday is a product of its time and more so proof that this film is important and should be taught today.The film is brilliant with its comedic timing. Whether it's the delayed reactions between each of the fast talking characters, or the insane and hectic phone conversations the writers are having throughout the picture, His Girl Friday has plenty of entertainment. You can definitely tell that it's based off of a play through the line delivery and its far-fetched plot, but everything works. It did a lot for films at the time as well. Hawks' big change from the play was the decision to make Hildy a woman. Not many films did something like that, if at all. Even today, you see far too little female roles on screen and His Girl Friday was one of the few films to change the story and add a female because it makes the plot far better. It's that type of progressive work that makes His Girl Friday a very important film then and now.+Grant is perfect+Witty+Phone conversations8.5/10

reviews.review_title: A dated chaotic comedy which is still enjoyable because of Grant and Russell's babbling.
reviews.content:
His Girl Friday (1940) :
Brief Review -A dated chaotic comedy which is still enjoyable because of Grant and Russell's babbling. Journalists could be bad or good, it's just a matter of which side they want to show with full conviction but what if we get to see both the sides together? Here comes Howard Hawks's His Girl Friday based on Journalism but exploring multiple genres like Drama, Romance, Comedy and little of satire. The film seems to be dated now cause many films have been made on hardcore journalism which left strong impact on society so a popcorn flick on such a universal concept might not be known as a Great Film. However, it can be called a Great Fun ride. We don't need to give stamp of Conceptual misunderstanding if Rom-com is one of the most popular genre for the audience. His Girl Friday doesn't make much sense in characterisations and thier behaviours are illogical too. But the babbling and tricks are 2 big things which makes it a terrific Comedy Flick which can be enjoyed multiple times. Sadly it fails to give justice to some big characters involved in the storyline because they had to give more space to the leading pair. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell's continuous chaos, arguments, quarrels and chatterbox gags are fantastically drawn. They might not make much sense if you are looking for quality but otherwise it is so much fun and laughs to see them tearing apart each other. The heavy rush of continuous disasters and Twists could have been handled sensitively and calmly but the screenplay failed to provide the moments. Maybe a sensible director like Howard Hawks could have looked into it and sorted it out if wanted but don't know why it did not happen. It could be because he wanted to keep it busy and chaotic, but if not then i am sorry. Even in positive manners, the sense was missing anyway so there is no point to discuss further on it. The bottom line is, His Girl Friday is ENTERTAINING and if it's the only thing that matters then BIG YES for it.RATING - 7/10*By - #samthebestest

Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell star as Walter Burns and Hildy Johnson respectively in one of the fastest-talking screwball comedies--make that movies--ever made. HIS GIRL FRIDAY is a clever script teeming with fab dialogue, delivered by a top-notch cast, and captured by one of the best directors of Hollywood's Golden Age, Howard Hawks. It makes you care about the characters, and about what happens to them; it makes you think and listen hard; in short, it makes you as a viewer do and feel things so many modern movies just can't be bothered with. If I have any kind of complaint about this movie at all, it's that there just wasn't enough screen-time for Cary Grant. (Is there ever?) He gives one of his best performances here--his Walter is fast-talking, cheating and conniving, with hardly any redeeming qualities... except that undeniable and inescapable charm Grant lends to all his characters. A fine and perfectly respectable way to spend a couple of hours. Watch this with someone--it might turn them onto classic movies, just as it did some people in the cinema with me today.

Usually I have issues with IMDb short summaries, but this time they nailed it. "A newspaper editor uses every trick in the book to keep his ace reporter ex-wife from remarrying." "His Girl Friday" is a screwball comedy, and one of the most hilarious I have ever seen. The screenplay is excellent and Howard Hawks has done a great job directing it. Cary Grant and beautiful Rosalind Russell have sparkling chemistry and the way they perform jokes is so natural and believable. But to fully enjoy this movie you have to be fluent in English. Watching it with subtitles simply won't do it, because the essence of this film's greatness is in its frantic pace. Plot twists are good, but the breathtakingly fast overlapping dialogue, simultaneous conversations and rapid-fire delivery of word gags, sarcastic insults, sexual innuendos and in-jokes are what ensured this movie's high place in the film history. 8,5/10

and dive in. From beginning to end, this film never lets up, shaking, rattling and rolling the viewer as each member of the cast tries to get their two cents into the mix before someone shouts them down. For once Grant is the conniver, not the connivee and how he does plot. No matter the setbacks to his ambitions, he has an answer to his desire to avoid losing his Hildy, and getting the story at the same time. Russell is his complete equal, barking back at him in spades, drowning him out at times. What a pair. Ralph Bellamy never has a chance. And the self-references: Grant noting that the last man who said something to him was Archibald Leach, or sending Louis out to look for Bruce, who looks like Ralph Bellamy.Reading on this board, I see many object to the humor of a man jumping out a window, or heading for the electric chair, but compared to modern use of cartoon violence, such as in Get Shorty, these episodes do not change the tone of the story.

reviews.review_title: Old news? Who Cares! His Girl Friday is still an interest dark screwball comedy.
reviews.content: This just in--- I like this movie. Directed by Howard Hawks, the movie is most famous for its clever fast-track dialogue, inside jokes, dark humor, and crafty one-liners/comebacks. This was really unheard of, from most 1940s film industry that was still kinda unsure in people wanted to see talkies or silent films. Indeed, it's one of the first, if not the first, films to have characters talk over the lines of other characters, for a more realistic sound. Prior to this, movie characters completed their lines before the next lines were started. It's in a rapid fire machine gun talking. I find it astonishing that human beings can talk this fast! The movie had lot of spontaneity and ad-libbing, and you really do see it. Honestly, if you take away much of the dialogue, you only got like 10 minutes of footage. There were some scenes that went a little too long in the pacing department, but it seem like it went fast, most of the time. The movie is adaptation by Charles Lederer, Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur of the play The Front Page by Hecht and MacArthur. The major change in this version, introduced by Hawks, is that the role of Hildy Johnson now played by female actress, Rosalind Russell. When director Howard Hawks was planning to make the film, he was going to cast a man for the part. While auditioning actors, a female secretary would read the lines belonging to that man part. Hawks loved the words coming from a woman so much, they decided to rewrite the part for a woman. Honestly, it's great to see a women actor in a more commanding equal role. It's also nice to see women, outside of the roles that normally you find in films from the 1940s that portray them as housewife, young unwed-daughters, or rich socialite. Honestly, I think this is one of the first movies that portray a newswoman. It shows that women are just as good in, gathering up the news, in what was once deem as a male's club only profession. Rosalind Russell is just as good as her co-star, Cary Grant, as Walter Burn, her ex-husband and ex-business partner. She indeed pretty much, carry the second half of the film, despite being Hawk's last choice to play Hildy. Yes, she did had help writing clever dialogue, by her brother. Still, she gave one-hell of a performance. One of Rosalind Russell's many gifts as an accomplished actress was her ability to act by not only words but by using great body language and amazing facial expressions. You see it, here. Cary Grant is just charming and funny as Walter Burns. It's odd to hear that 1940s critics thought he was badly miscast as Walter and Clark Gable would made a better choice. In my opinion, I do believe that, if you put Cary Grant in this movie against Clark Gable in 1934's It Happen One Night, you can see Cary Grant channeling his inner Clark Gable impression. No matter, what. Cary Grant was great in the role. There was still a bit of things that he did that was a bit unlikeable, but for the most part, he seem right man to play the wise cracking, always get what he wants, Walter Burns.
