This screwball comedy by Howard Hawks is mixed with slapstick comedy. This isn't my favorite old comedy movie but still kept my attention and was pretty humorous. This comedy is very fast paced and I thought it was hard to keep up with it at points throughout the movie. Cary Grant (Walter Burns) and Rosalind Russell (Hildy Johnson) do make a great pair in this movie as rival reporters. Rosalind Russel never loses drive and keeps up with the other reporters who are mostly men. She is funny throughout and my favorite scene involving her was when she tackled the man when she was running down the street. Overall I wouldn't give it an 8/10 but a 6/10.

reviews.review_title: The life she wants vs. The life she knows
reviews.content: Hildy is a beautiful, spunky, newspaper journalist that longs to have a normal life and get away from all the the newspaper business and her ex- husband. Hildy was set in her ways in the beginning, but throughout the movie became more involved in the hot murder story of Earl William. This film and Hildy's life is great for the audience to watch and experience because many people have become torn between two things in their life whether it had to do with two possible love interest or two job opportunities. If she would have chosen Bruce she would of possibly had a lot easier life, stress free normal life, but let face it sometimes we the audience don't want that life. As far as the film,their wasn't much movement of change in the types of shots, but it did well for with the action that was going on and felt as if you were there in the room along with them. The anxiety towards the end when Bruce is trying to get Hildy's attention was a great scene because of the amount of rambling and typewriting going on. The scenes felt cleverly put together and easy to watch.

reviews.review_title: Cary Grant makes every scene funny to watch.
reviews.content: With this movie I wasn't sure what to expect from it. At first I thought that this was meant to be a romantic film where Cary Grant would try to win back the love of his ex wife. But I was so wrong. Instead, every scene is filled with comedy and then you realize that this isn't meant to be a serious film. The one thing that bothered me though is that the film seems like there is a very strong presence of gray colors. There are hardly ever any other colors but it seems that everything is just so bland. Plus another small thing that I was bothered by was the fact that dialogue would be spoken so quickly that you have a hard time understanding what was said. Either way, by the end of it the movie was better than what I expected. It's right on the same plain as any other screwball comedy. And if you have the time definitely check it out.

reviews.review_title: One of the great screwball comedies
reviews.content: Howard Hawks realized that "The Front Page" had a love story in it, so he turned it into the hilarious "His Girl Friday." Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell have never been better in this fast-paced movie that combines a romance with a satire of crime and media. Thanks to the vibrant energy and cynicism, and the overlapping dialogue, this movie is just as fresh 61 years later. Also, anyone who likes this film should check out the films of Preston Sturges.

reviews.review_title: Amazing, would have liked more sets, and for more characters to be developed
reviews.content: The frantic busyness throughout kept me engaged throughout. I never thought dialogue could be this exciting, in the past even good dialogue gets boring after a while for me.She is a strong female character who wants to convince herself that she can live a normal life, but her passion for the newspaper is keeping her away from a normal life, and she isn't willing to admit that. I feel she shouldn't have continued to fall for his plans however, she should know him better.Nice tracking shot going through the office. Great references even I could get.

reviews.review_title: A brilliantly acted descent into madness.
reviews.content: This film was not at all what I expected when I started watching it. Advertised as a romantic comedy, starring one of my favorite actors whose romantic comedies I have always enjoyed, I fully expected this movie to be another classic romp like Bringing Up Baby, I was a Male War Bride, Arsenic and Old Lace, or the Philadelphia Story. Instead, after the opening scenes introducing the characters, nearly all of the humor seems to be mean-spirited and manipulative, or very darkly satirical. The only romance the main characters engaged in was with their own egos and the thrill of hunting down sensational stories, abandoning sense, decency and professionalism along the way.It may be possible that I'm simply lacking some crucial context that would cause any of this to make sense, but I found this film to be very distressing, even disturbing at times. The scene with Mollie's introduction I thought was rather poignant, with how guilty the reporters looked and acted afterwards, but for the rest of the film, they completely disregard any of that remorse and fight over every scrap they can get, eventually leading to a fatal or near-fatal tragedy. I cannot imagine how a distraught young woman leaping out of a high window to protect her confused and terrified friend from being murdered for political gain could be construed as comedy, or how I could empathize with the main characters after how callously they regard the whole situation. There were other faults I found but that was the moment I started feeling a bewildered hatred towards this movie.The acting is great throughout, I must say, but I've never liked despicable protagonists. I can abide antiheroes with a soft spot or two, but the only positive trait His Girl Friday's main characters have is cleverness and that's just not enough.

reviews.review_title: deft, clever, classy and smart -- no wonder His Girl Friday is a classic
reviews.content: Not much more can be said about His Girl Friday that hasn't been said before, except to note that the kind of class and style it represents seems so inappropriate nowadays, given our contemporary penchant for sadism, nihilism and paranoia (sometimes euphemistically called 'doom and gloom.') None of these will be found in this light, breezy, witty film, justly famed for its dialog, which features just the right amount of jibes at petty bureaucrats, government officials, political bosses and capital punishment. Director Howard Hawkes' camera flits around the claustrophobic set (entirely in the Press Room of the local police precinct where unjustly condemned prisoner Williams has been bound over for 'justice'to the corrupt Mayor and his henchmen) creating heightened tension which finds release in the barbed wit (Sample: "Say, I hear you're consorting with Stalin now?" "Yeah, they say you wear red underwear" -- would anyone under age 30 even catch the reference to 'red,' an early (and pejorative) term for Communist -- from the red of the former USSR's flag)? But never mind -- there are few dated references; most of the dialog is as fresh and clever today as it was in 1940. And the plot -- as newspaperman Grant tries to woo back ex-wife Rosalind Russell -- unfolds as easy on the eye as on the ear, with quick-reflex performances from the leads and rollicking assistance from Hawkes' impeccable style and deftness with the camera. A film easy to watch and a delight to contemplate, His Girl Friday deserves a paraphrase of the Earl of Southwell -- "Easy film-watching's darn hard film-making."

His Girl Friday is a classic that still holds water today. Howard Hawks delivers an adaptation of Ben Hecht's play, The Front Page, that is funnier and more fine tuned than most comedies today. This film's influence is still felt today with movies like Clerks and Pulp Fiction with their quick and witty dialogue.From the beginning, this film will hypnotize you with its ultra fast dialogue. The exchanges seems so meticulously rehearsed and prepared. Characters hit their lines with complete perfection and air-tight pace. There is probably ten seconds in the whole film where nothing is being said. This masterful use of dialogue can easily be credited to director Hawks, but it is the performance of Cary Grant that drives this film. He plays a corrupt, immoral, and unethical newspaper editor who forces us to like him. The entire film shows us how evil a newspaper can be but it shows us from their point of view. This enables us to empathize with Cary Grant and his staff. They lie to and set up Bruce Baldwin. That should make us dislike them and position them as the villains of the film. However, Cary Grant's performance is so engaging that we end up admiring the level of power he has and the intelligence he displays. He takes what would be a villain in most movies and makes him likable. He almost acts as a lawyer or politician with how slick he is. His upbeat delivery of lines and dry humor show the dialogue in another light, from his point of view. His intentions are to serve his newspaper and his ex-wife, Hildy. This film should be re-released today so people can see what real comedy is. Not just some random and pointless comment that makes no sense we can't help but laugh. That seems to be what comedy is today (Family Guy, Dane Cook, Seth Rogen, etc.). His Girl Friday is a smart comedy with relevant jokes that build character.Go see it.

This movie was actually quite funny, I think what made it so was the great personas that were displayed on screen. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell did a great job together, their back and forth was so natural. The story itself was great too, especially how they managed to add so many little things to make the story more interesting. The time crunch that they had, the murder, Hildy and Walter's previous relationship, Hildy's impending marriage to another man. This is screwball at it's finest. Perhaps my favorite part was seeing Hildy kick her new beau to the curb when she realized he just wasn't as important to her. He was obviously not right for her and she was just using him to get over Walter. Walter's meddling ways were definitely an asset to the story and the comedy particularly when he was using them to mess up Hildy's plans to leave and sending her fiancée to jail several times in the process. Great story, great movie.

Gary Grant and Rosalind Russell pulled off a great Film "His Girl Friday". This film is fun and exciting and most definitely a classic that needs to be appreciated. Director Howard Hawks is fantastic and you can tell that he is very organized and straight forward. As a Black and White film the lighting in certain scenes are perfect and really grab the attention of the audience. The Cinematography can not go without recognition and Joseph Walker does everything he can to make a perfect picture. Whats interesting is the way Director Howard Hawks uses his characters and the detail he goes in with the plot and story line is excellent!

This movie has always been one of my favorites. The Front Page contains classic story lines which allowed it to still work decades later as a play or movie. It was done at my school and I did props and costumes. I can recite every line. This takes the rapid fire dialogue (revolutionary at the time) to a new level. Changing Hildy to a woman was inspirational. Bellamy plays the dull, deadpan fiancé perfectly. The poor man and his mother had no idea what they were getting into. So much is perfect in every way EXCEPT costumes. Her suits and hats are absolutely ugly. Those stripes leave me screaming, "my eyes, my eyes." They make me want to steal Walter's watch. Maybe Duffy can save the day.

I love how Howard Hawkes directed such a variety of films during his career and this was probably the funniest one. Cary Grant gives a great performance as Walter and will do whatever it takes to stop the wedding of his ex-wife. I didn't expect this film to be this funny especially since I had only seen Cary Grant in one other movie and it was a suspense film. This film is one of the concluding films for the screwball comedy genre which would eventually end in the early 1940's but as the genre expanded all of the films got funnier. This film is a must see for todays comedy fan and it is great to watch Cary Grant give a great performance in the middle of his acting career.

"His Girl Friday" is definitely a great comedy for not only its time but for today as well. There was such a great chemistry between Hildy and Walter that really made the movie. The movie definitely would not have work as well if they didn't have the great dynamic. It makes you wonder that if this is how they are being divorced, how was it when they were married. I have to also give credit to Bruce (Ralph Bellamy) for being kind of oblivious to being constantly pushed around by the dynamic duo. There was just great humor throughout the film that helped keep me hooked. And even through the whole movie took place in only a few sets, you could barely notice thanks to the constant humor that the two bickering divorcees made. Maybe not my favorite screwball comedy but definitely a pretty good one at that.

This film was a really good one, and it has been impressing people a lot since it was first released. It was funny, heartwarming, and really energetic at the same time. The film was so good that I found it interesting. When I first heard of comedies like this, it really got me getting into some laughs. I remember a lot of moments when Walter and Hildebrand (a.k.a. "Hildy") were together, and that was when I knew that something was going to happen. It really got me into laughing at a lot of what they do. It seems that people have been loving comedies, whether they're shows or movies, and people would want to see them again. It will keep saying, "Watch me again!" in my mind.

His Girl Friday is a mix between a normal screwball comedy and an early form of romantic comedy, and it is one of the best ones I have seen. Right from the beginning the fast paced dialog draws you in, and you are determined to not miss a beat. There is a bunch of overlapping lines that give the film a realistic feel to the arguing that is going on. The one liners in this film are also gold. It is written so well and will keep you laughing the whole way through. The chemistry between the cast is also a key figure to the greatness of the film. They all seem to mix so well together, even during arguments, that it feels real. If you want to laugh, this is a must see.

reviews.review_title: His Girl Friday - He'll Do Anything
reviews.content: His Girl Friday was released in 1940 and was directed by Howard Hawks. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell have great chemistry on screen and do a fantastic job at making the crazy relationship between Walter Burns and Hildy Johnson a reality. The fast pace of the film makes the hour and half fly by, although the insanity between Burns and Johnson does get a little tiring after a while. It becomes obvious after a short period of time Johnson divorced Burns, but his antics makes him a lovable fool. The script writing is fantastic! The jokes range from witty puns to very clever political cracks. The costume design was good. The only notable costume pieces were Burns' suits and Johnsons hats. Overall the film is a successful screwball comedy, but I could have done with less shouting and people talking over the top of each other. It made the film difficult to understand at times and took away from the films quality.

There was not much of a set in this movie. It was very simple and stayed with 3 main sets which kept it easy to follow. Even though this movie was made over 50 years ago, I still found the comedy to be funny, I caught myself laughing more than I thought I would. Howard Hawks used short and quick humor to his benefit. Cary Grant starred in this movie and he did a great job just like he always does; Rosalind Russell also did her part to make this film a classic. Both of them carried themselves in a recognizable comedic manner. A bit about the movie, Walter and Hildy are a divorced couple that can not work together. Walter wants to be back with her but she already has another man. Walter wants Hildy to work for her again and write a story on a murder case but she keeps denying him. This gets the two into a hilarious and entertaining pickle. I was very pleased by this movie and urge people to see it, This movie is a classic for a reason, to have people from all generations watch it.

Cary Grant is doing what he does best in His Girl Friday--gruff-but-witty comedy. The realistic dialogue between him and Rosalind Russell as they play ex-spouses Walter and Hildy adds a lot to the sincerity of the comedy in the film. In fact, it's so fast-paced that the jokes alone seem to be moving the story along. When the other noise factors are considered, including (near constantly) ringing phones and the like, it can get almost overwhelming.Sound as an emotional tool is something that I'd find more typical of a dramatic film. But the stressful, fast-paced, noise-filled aspects of this movie (that permeate what would normally be portrayed as some simple, straight-forward situations or conversations) has a lot to tell about Walter's personality, Hildy's true nature, and the often morally ambiguous (or often just corrupt) life and career of "newspaper men" that the film warns the audience about right in the beginning. It was completely effective in doing so, but it honestly made me very anxious, which took away from some of the jokes.The jokes themselves, while witty, were sometimes quite topical, and I felt it aged the movie a bit. The story of things getting exploited and spun out of proportion by the press however, is fairly ageless.The cinematography itself was very straightforward. Visually, there weren't too many artful decisions. Not in costumes, framing, light, etc. This was not exactly disappointing, however, as it is a straightforward comedy and to expect a ton more seems unfair.

'His Girl Friday' had me howling with laughter from the first(seemingly endless) string of words. Probably the fastesttalking talkie ever made. Grant and Russell sizzle throughout,and Bellamy provides the perfect third point in the triangle...in the fast-paced, dog-eat-dog world of journalism, a nicemild-mannered guy like Bruce Baldwin is sure to get eaten alive.("That guy looks like Ralph Bellamy" - ROFL!) Grant's timing anddelivery are superb... apart from Gary Cooper, has there everbeen a more suave, charming leading man? And Russell goes toothand jowl with him the whole time. Warrants repeat viewings tocatch all of the dialogue you miss while laughing. Delightful.

His girl Friday was good. That is all I can say about it though. The lead actor, Cary Grant, seemed slightly out of pace amongst the constant yelling. Usually this is what makes comedies of the era shine, yet Grant felt completely out of place amongst it, in a way that limited the comedy instead of creating it. For the most part, this movie had its moments, but lacked the great acting that made other movies like My Man Godfrey so good

First off I love Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell is such a spitfire. All through the movie I really didn't like Cary's character Walter. He was the epitome of egotism. But then way towards the end I could tell that he really did care about Rosalind's character Hildy and was the only one who could handle her. When those two got into it with each other there was no stopping them. And poor Bruce he had no idea what he had gotten himself into with Hildy. And John Qualen who plays Earl William is one odd fellow in this movie. I still don't know if he committed the crime or not, he seems to sweet but then he shot a man to escape. The whole part where he was hiding in the desk was priceless.

I didn't realize how much I love screwball comedies until watching "My Man Godfrey" in film class, but then I couldn't wait to watch another (and more!). "His Girl Friday" was a great pick—I love Rosalind Russell and she gives such great life into Hildy's character. The fast pace of the entire flick kept my constant attention (and honestly felt like sitting around the table at holidays with family—everyone talking at once!). The subtle jokes could easily be missed if one wasn't paying attention, like the mention of Bellamy's character looking like "that guy from the movies, Bellamy." Ha! Of course Cary Grant is wonderful as ever in using his facial expressions to convey what he's really thinking for the audience even if other characters aren't meant to notice. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who needs an introduction into the genre.

Great movie very funny I love the way the ex husband keeps involving his wife in everything that is going on even though she is trying to leave him and be with her new husband it's great to see the different plots and twist that were in this movie in the way that the comedy was at this time compared to the type of comedies that we have to this day.. great movie loved watching it would watch again. If you have not seen this movie please take some time to watch it very good movie very funny there are many different things in this movie that I could relate to I'm sure many other people that watch it could relate to similar things or different parts of this movie about adversity, need and about trying to capture your own way of life.

reviews.review_title: "His girl Friday" gets a Sunday review
reviews.content: 1940 "His girl Friday" (Howard Hawks) is so fun to watch. its fast paced, witty dialogue is incredibly amusing and fuels the development of our two protagonists Hildy(Rosalind Russell) and Mr. burns(Cary grant). two of which are wildly funny especially while bickering and following each others antics. Rivals or partners with Hildy and Walter its very hard to tell and might as well be both. they take there work and each other very personally which I believe is what caused many of the issues which transpired through out the film and made for a suspenseful story line. this film must of influenced the paper business for years to come.

Loved this movie most older movies i wasn't really interested in, but this one was really good. I noticed that everyone was a smoker. They smoked all the time and everywhere they could. Outfits never changed. everyone was always wearing the same outfit and carrying a hat or wearing one even the women, they also carried around umbrellas. I feel that this was a very fast paced movie things happened really quick. I guess thats where there get screwball comedy from. It was really funny though. especially when Mr. Butler does everything possible to get his wife back. He comes up with fake money and lies about everything to get his ex wife and soon to be new husband to not make it to Albany to marry. I was surprised that Albany was even in or discussed in the movie. It really was a good movie. Megan H

Cary Grant is one of my top 10 favorite actors of all time. He's hilarious and serious and everything a good actor should be. This film was really cute, as it showcased his acting abilities as well as Rosalind Russel. One of the best parts of this movie was how fast all of the characters move. They were deliberately told to be as fast as possible for effect. The pacing is probably one of the best parts of this film, as it matches the stereotypical "news reporter" quickness. One part that I thought was hilarious was how Grant character mentioned the name "Archie Leach". Cary Grant's birth name is Archibauld Leach. It's those kinds of subtle yet hilarious things that make screwball comedies the best.

This film was tough to follow at first because of all the dialogue but soon enough i was into it and did actually enjoy watching the whacked out relationship Walter and Hildy had. The movie is very fast paced so it wouldn't be recommended for younger viewers because the story might get confusing and the jokes might not make sense to them. Both the acting and directing of this film are both top notch work and really help pull everything together in the plot. I found it interesting that a comedy movie could dip it's toes in touchy subject matter (murder, execution, suicide) and still be funny from started to finish especially in the 1940's. The nice mixture of romantic comedy and satire help the flow of the film as do the supporting roles. Another great screwball comedy from a golden era of movie making. If you are thinking of seeing this movie stop debating on what to watch and let Howard Hanks work his magic. I almost wish Walter and Hildy had worked things out.

This is not a comedy. This is a horrible movie. I didn't laugh at all. A lady jumps out a window? Police spray the building with bullets? This is funny? Cary Grant is a pushy, self important editor who thinks he can do whatever he wants. Maybe all this was funny in 1940, but I didn't find it funny at all. Wasted my evening watching it. Should have taken a shower instead, better use of time.And remember, this is my opinion.

reviews.review_title: First experience with Howard Hawks guarantees revisiting his work
reviews.content: For as wonderful as Cary Grant (Walter Burns) and Rosalind Russell (Hildy Johnson) are in His Girl Friday, I knew that I couldn't pass up an opportunity to discuss Howard Hawks' direction.I do not often notice movement as a staple of direction when I'm watching a film - especially not when it is the first time I have seen the film - but here I am. I couldn't help but notice is in His Girl Friday. Hawks creates the semblance of a dance between the characters of the film. It start with how fluid the dialogue is between characters. Characters start talking before another character finishes, it sets a wonderful, fast pace for the film. Hawks doesn't stop there though. he doesn't let the characters just talk to one another, he moves them around the environment they inhabit. Occasionally interacting physically with each other and the objects in the surrounding environment. It matches the pace of the dialogue to a tee. What this does is draw the comedy - often biting in this case - from the seemingly benign scenes. It is a testament to how to effectively construct a comedy out of a story that does not necessarily need it. And that's just it, it's hilarious. If you're even briefly considering watching His Girl Friday, do yourself a favor and throw it on.

reviews.review_title: This film will have you filled with laughter
reviews.content: His Girl Friday, a hilarious film of the 40s, is a must see! Journalist Hildy Johnson finds herself in a heap of trouble and pranks when she returns to see her ex-husband (Walter Burns) one last time. She introduces him to her current fiancée, Bruce Baldwin, and the problems with Walter soon arise. He has his people play trick after trick on Hildy and Bruce to get them to stay and to win Hildy back. She refuses all of the tricks and offers until she uncovers a front page story which gets hotter and hotter. During the film, the group captures an escaped convict and hide him in plain sight. This comedy is hilarious and witty. With it's fast humor it will have you glued to your seat and enraged with laughter!

I thoroughly enjoyed watching His Girl Friday. It was a great movie that I would watch again just for pleasure and not as a requirement for class. Also considered to be a screw ball comedy like My Man Godfrey, they were made 4 years apart and in the Golden Age of making movies and both were excellent not only as comedies but also just in the film sense. His Girl Friday was funny from start to finish, had comedy, betrayal, rekindling, drama and anything else you could think of happening in a movie. I thought the acting of Cary Grant was phenomenal in every way. He really made me want to continue to watch the movie and not miss anything. Even trying to be the bad guy he is a good guy and i really enjoyed watching his acting as well as Rosalind Russell. Both were superb. I would recommend this to everyone as a classic 1930's screwball comedy but also just as great movie that you can watch over and over.

reviews.review_title: One of Screwball comedies best films
reviews.content: Cary Grant is one of my favorite actors in the screwball comedy genre, especially when he played Walter Burns. He was able to talk his way out of any situation and had everyone playing by his rules without even knowing it. He even wound up with Hildy, even though she was so sure she was getting out of the paper business and going to Mary Bruce. This movie really pushed the bounds of the code which made this film even funnier. This film was serious, funny, it had a love triangle, and a crime what else could you ask for in a movie..

reviews.review_title: Not the Definitive Screwball Comedy, But Still Enjoyable
reviews.content: Cary Grant is head of a newspaper business, and was previously married to Rosalind Russell, who now wants to leave her business job to marry nerdy Ralph Bellamy. Grant wants Russell to come back to him, and deliberately devises schemes to eliminate Bellamy from Russell during the most insane (and mostly false) news story in the history of news stories.The film has been described by many fans as "the definitive screwball comedy." But is it really? There's some really insane comedic moments in the film that make the film fun as it is, such as the brilliant chemistry between Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell and the insane, super fast talking used throughout the picture, but it's not a perfect film. I didn't care too much for the behind the scenes frame-up news story that plays a major part in a film. It just seemed too forced in what's supposed to be a comedy. Another scene where a character commits suicide also seems out of place in a comedy. But like with other flawed films, when Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell are on screen together, sparks fly and the film's extremely fun to watch.It may not be the greatest screwball comedy ever made (I have a higher preference for Bringing Up Baby and You Can't Take it With You), but Howard Hawks delivers in making an enjoyable film nonetheless.

reviews.review_title: Must see if you enjoy slapstick comedy
reviews.content: This film was really funny! Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell were perfect for their roles as Walter Burns and Hildy Johnson, respectively, and Ralph Bellamy is great as the dimwit Bruce Baldwin who rivals Grant's character in his search for Hildy's affections. What really made this movie stand out was its fast-paced dialogue and action, which the fantastic cast pulled off perfectly. The dialogue was so fast that the characters often spoke over each other. This was a fantastic choice by director Howard Hawks that is reflective of the ever-changing newsroom environment to which Hildy and Walter belong. The fast and well-written dialogue also makes the film a great slapstick comedy; Grant and Russell are able to deliver lines quickly but hilariously. This movie is a must see for anyone who loves slapstick comedy, and one that I thoroughly enjoyed.

reviews.review_title: Hilarious film that deserves a watch!
reviews.content: Rather than posting a bit of the synopsis, although I might reference some scenes and such, I just want to say: ANYONE WHO ADORES COMEDIES, PARTICULARLY SCREWBALLS SHOULD WATCH THIS. I really loved it although I'm not sure if there was much chemistry between Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell. Like most screwballs I've watched, this one also sets place in a newspaper publisher (The Morning Post), which already sets up the stage for people talking over each other and quick dialogue. Russell is Hildegaard (Hildy), the ex-wife of Grant, who is Walter Burns the editor of The Morning Post, and of course, it's obvious that Walter is going to try to get Hildy back. And like most screwballs, Hildy already has another man! While the story is quite predictable, it's the acting on Russell's end and sometimes Grant's that makes this film great. I knew what was going to happen, but the quick dialogue is what kept me watching. I could have cared less about the whole newspaper story, but I couldn't keep my eyes off of Russell. Grant had some great moments when he would make these weird groaning/moaning noises that were perfect for the scene. Ralph Bellamy plays Bruce, and of course, he is the guy Hildy is going to marry, but if you've watched some screwballs, you probably know what happens to Bruce in the end. There was a great line when Walter tells one of his assistants to find Bruce and when he describes Bruce, he says, "He looks like that fellow in the movies - Ralph Bellamy." I should be on the look out for more movie references in screwballs since I noticed one in Bringing Up Baby as well. It was nice to see Ralph Bellamy again since I saw him in The Awful Truth as well and he pretty much played the same character, which made me chuckle a bit. And how could I not mention Howard Hawks in this post, right? For those who don't know, Hawks is a well-known director by film buffs and has directed numerous famous films. Maybe you know him as the director of Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (you know, the film with Marilyn Monroe singing "Diamonds are a Girl's Best Friend"!) but let me tell you, he has never disappointed me with any of his films. I loved how he used some subtleties like in a scene when Hildy, Bruce, and Walter are at a restaurant and with the things they ordered and their actions, it was as if it was foreshadowing the ending of this film. First it starts with Walter deciding what he'll get and Hildy simply saying that she'll get the same, and Bruce kind of goes with it as well. Then both Hildy and Walter take out cigarettes and when Hildy lights a match, Walter simply drags Hildy's match over to his cigarette and Hildy gives him a look of annoyance and then lights her own cigarette. I noticed that Bruce didn't smoke in the scene and then Walter orders coffee with rum and Hildy gets the same thing, but Bruce says that he doesn't want it. After watching the film, I realized that the scene (the one I just mentioned) was the film in a nutshell. At the beginning, it all appears to be that the three characters are on an equal plane, yet it is Walter who orders first in a forceful voice and when Hildy orders the same in a simple manner, it was as if ordering the roast beef sandwich was something they usually did and was nothing new to her. Then when they both start smoking and Walter doing the thing he does with the match, it's like bringing Walter and Hildy together and finally with the coffee, it is solidifying the bond between Walter and Hildy while Bruce is in the outskirts. Well, that's just my interpretations of things, but I thought that Hawks directed that scene and the rest of the film incredibly well. I highly suggest that you watch this film if you're up for a good laugh. reviews.review_title: possibly the greatest comedy ever made
reviews.content: His Girl Friday is one of the rare comic films that is not only hilarious but actually changed how films are made (or at least written).  Director Howard Hawks' adaptation of The Front Page was the first time that lines were written specifically to be overlapped and Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell grab hold of those lines and never let go.  This film is full speed comedy that never lets up.

The beginning is kind of an open book you can pretty much see what's going to happen. It also a fast past fast talking comedy if you don't pay attraction you may miss something. Also a lot of one liners her and there that gets throw around the rooms. And through the movie the girl shows signs of being good at and loving the job she used to do more and more as the movies goes on and also how much she knows her ex-husband. As for the ex-husband he is very presentment and also plays on how much he knows her. The acting is very believable, I think the two main actors work together very well almost perfectly. The storyline also shows how powerful a newspaper can be.

His Girl Friday (1940) from Howard Hawksis an intriguing comedy. The film is humerus while the plot leaves most of the story to the imagination. The antagonist is a strong woman named Hildy Johnson played by Rosalind Russell. It is great to see an independent woman in a film taking place in the 1940s. The dialog starts off incredibly fast and stays that way. I feel that much of the humor is created by confusion. The film slows towards the middle. The press room scenes (where most of the film took place) had me falling asleep. I found some topics not so funny such as suicide. The film lacks the silliness that is found in other screwball comedies, it is not worth checking out.

Well this movie was a lot like "My Man Godfrey" but that is not a bad thing. This particular movie has a more in depth plot.. or maybe not. Anyway, this movie had great fluidity although at times it seemed like too much was going on. I enjoyed the characters, they give you a good idea of how newspaper journalists used to work back in the day. You learn things about the past and how things used to be through old movies such as these. The plot was great and it had several twists that you never see coming. I feel bad for the main character a little but later you learn that everything works out well. I thoroughly enjoyed the movie and recommend it!

reviews.review_title: A newspaper editor tries to keep his ex wife away from a new man
reviews.content: His Girl Friday is a screw ball comedy in which the comedic elements draw on the protagonists attempt to keep his ex wife from ending up with a new man. The film's dialogue is quick and has a punchy element to it. This is interesting to me, as I am a stand up comic...and one piece of simple advice for delivery, given by Jerry Seinfeld, "loud and fast." He says this is 80% of funny. And this film utilizes this concept all dialogue makes you WANT to laugh. Though I must admit, some of the dialogue itself didn't necessarily translate over the times...though for some people it may have, it is a very subjective idea, humor.

reviews.review_title: Fast paced witty Screwball Comedy with strong Female Leads
reviews.content: I thought that this was extremely witty and fast paced, for a screwball comedy it had a good plot, you had to really pay attention because of how fast the dialogue was, many times characters overlapped each other and exchanged witty come backs and punchlines, there was a lot of dark humor which I found worked really well with the script. It seemed realistic, the characters and writer did a good job with making sure the dialogue was as real as possible, the lighting and cinematographic was very simple and basic which added to the realism of the movie. . it was hilarious to watch how Burns consistently gets Baldwin arrested over and over again. I liked the scheme he used to try to keep Johnson from marrying Baldwin.

This is one of the great classics of all time. The dialog is fast, funny and smart. Plus, the gender treatment is fascinating, and not dated in the slightest. I think the movie still shows a lot of resemblance to the press today. they are all fighting and scheming to get the best story. The best part of the movie is when capture Earl Williams because each reporter has a different version of the story. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell did a fantastic job acting in this movie. It was very fast paced, but their dialogue was quick and witty. The dialogue had to be fast because life in a newsroom is always going at 100 miles per hour. The only thing i did not care for about this movie is that you never really get to know much about the characters, you don't get inside their heads, but I think it's all part of the screwball comedy aspect of the film.

reviews.review_title: A classic in the world of comedy
reviews.content: Although screwball comedies were a thing of the 1930's around the Great Depression, they can still entertain just as well today as they did back then.In Howard Hawks' classic "His Girl Friday" a newspaper editor (Cary Grant) tries to win back his ex (Rosalind Russell) before she decides to settle down with another man (Ralph Bellamy) and leave her old life behind her.Hawks' is undoubtedly a great director. For it's time, the film was an entertaining marvel. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell are irresistible and really the strong points of this movie. Their chemistry and fast paced responses keep the film moving.Because the newspaper industry is prevalent in the film, many of the characters are affected by this and thus, the actors have a tendency to speak rather quickly. This works for comedic effect but some viewers may be turned off by this fast paced dialog.Ironically, the film felt slow for me at certain points. I believe however that this just might be a personal fault, as I'm used to watching so many modern films.Overall however, this is a great film for those who are fans of the screwball comedy genre. The rest of us will enjoy it just as much.

Hildy Johnson makes quite the spunky female character: independent, boisterous, take-charge. She really livens the movie up. There are some scenes to this movie which are really far-fetched. There's the scene where the lady jumps two stories to the streets below. How is she still alive? Then, there's the final scene with the murderer, where they hide him inside a desk to avoid his detection. How he managed to survive that long without air is beyond me, and even more bizarre is that when they pull him out, he's still alive, too. I would have liked to see the wedding between Hildy and her former ex-husband at the end of the movie; I can't believe he didn't take her on a Honeymoon the first time around.... Overall, well put together movie, but not without its flaws.

The two main actors in the film His Girl Friday were fantastic. Both Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell were absolutely hilarious throughout the entirety of this film. This romantic screwball comedy was a film that keeps you entertained and interested all the way until the very end, I couldn't stop watching it. In my own personal opinion i would have to say that His Girl Friday had somewhat of a Feminist twist to it. While watching as this film unfold we see the struggles that can be faced in marriage and how Walter schemes and makes plans to fight to win Hildy back. One thing that i really enjoyed about this film was the "inside jokes" that were made throughout the film, one was made that talks about Carey Grants real name. Overall i thought this was a very interesting comedy that kept you laughing and had a show down between male and female.

As someone who isn't a fan of the old screwball comedies, the film is actually pretty funny. I don't normally find the humor in screwball comedy, but His Girl Friday did it right. The witty banter conversations are unrealistic, but can't be taken too seriously considering the genre. It was remarkable how quickly they were speaking throughout the movie. It was as if the script was twice as long as anticipated and they had to babble through to finish it all. The speed adds comedic value, though. A lot of times throughout the film people were talking over each other to create a more realistic context of conversation when arguing or excited about something. I thought this was rather advanced dialogue for a 1940 film. I would definitely recommend this film.

His Girl Friday was a superb screwball comedy, featuring a perfectly assembled cast in Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell as two news reporters. I thought that they both played their roles amazingly, as Cary Grant is a master at the screwball genre. The film includes a very fast-paced environment, much like what a real life reporter's daily life would be like. The characters spoke very quickly, and this film is the first/ one of the first films to ever have characters talk over one another's lines. This created a more authentic experience, making it seem as if this were a real life discussion instead of one created by writers. The comedy was driven through creative dialogue, as Grant's character had many deadpan lines throughout that you had to really pay attention to understand, as did Russell. The love story seems to take a backseat, so that we could truly appreciate the humor and delivery of the characters. The photography was great, and it being from 1940 caused no issues in terms of the smooth editing. The lighting wasn't dim, and we could see what is happening quite well. The mis-en-scene was wonderful, as each scene included accurately dressed characters, and nice background props to give a sense of where they actually were. The movie took place in only a couple of rooms, and they were very simple. There was not too much going on to distract the audience, to ensure that Cary and Rosalind were rightfully the center of attention for the entirety of the film.

reviews.review_title: A screwball comedy that still manages to hold up
reviews.content: His Girl Friday (1940), Howard Hawks tells the story of a newspaper editor (played by Cary Grant) dead set on recapturing the interest of his former wife (played by Rosalind Russell) before she remarries. For a comedy over sixty year old I was impressed by how entertained I was. While the Communist jokes are so obviously irrelevant today (just a part of the times) the quips and comebacks are still sharp and witty. The acting is quite strong and the actors do a commendable job with the snappy dialogue. While the cinematography is hardly ground breaking it is well done and besides, is not the focus of this film. While I thought the end of the movie got a little darker then it needed to, His Girl Friday was overall a very enjoyable watch.

His Girl Friday is, as the summary suggests, a fast paced comedy with intelligently written characters. Rosalind Russel's Hildy Johnson demands your attention as soon as the film starts. With her front and center of the camera, and an outfit that stands out, Russel's performance is immediately exciting and with it brings that same excitement throughout the film. For being 77 years old, this film's comedic material still holds up, however the aforementioned pacing can produce issues. Sometimes the jokes come too fast, and it can be difficult to register them all. In addition the normal dialogue can be lost in the motor-mouthing that practically every character exhibits. While it is entertaining and without question, rather impressive that the actors can speak so quickly, it loses something in the process. These quick remarks come frequently and as a result the dialogue can be hard to relate to. It loses a sense of realism when every character is rambling on so quickly. Nobody talks like this, and if there were only say, one or two characters (like the main leads) that spoke this way it'd be less of a problem. However, as it stands it does lessen one's enjoyment. That being said, the jokes that do hit and the clever dialogue that isn't missed provides good entertainment.

I think "His Girl Friday" is an interesting film with humor but some times bores the audience. The film has good lighting and sound for its time but also isn't anything to write home about. Neither really adds or subtracts from the film. The humor in the movie is good at times and keeps the audience entertained. However there are long segments of the film that are just boring. This may be because humor has changed since the 1940s. The filming is also kind of poor, the camera often has these way too long shots. This film is amusing but I would not consider it a classic.

reviews.review_title: You can't hide from what you are passionate about
reviews.content: Hildy Johnson was the ex-wife of the fast talking editor Walter Burns. Walter was still in love with Hildy and pretended to take the news well when Hildy told him that she was to marry again. I liked the comedy in this movie, Walter knew that Hildy was passionate about being a reporter so he decided that was the angle he was going to use to get her back. It did not help that Hildy's fiancé was a little but naïve and just wanted a simple life. I think the funniest scene is when Walter wanted to be introduced to his ex-wife's fiancé and he went up to the older gentleman to congratulate him. I laughed out loud! Walter eventually pursued Hildy and it was actually successful. I didn't see the ending coming so it was a surprise to me. I would recommend this movie if someone was into screwball comedies. The dialogue is very fast, its filled with zingers that will keep you laughing.

His Girl Friday is a romantic comedy built around the lives of news reporters and their relationship with one another and their careers. The criminal was not the best he seemed a little shady. The film would have been better if the dialogue was slower, sometimes you could not understand it. His Girl Friday significantly told us to not be someone you are not. Hildy tried to be someone she was not by trying to become a "stay at home" women. That ended when she knew that that was not for her and already had the things she loved the most her job and her ex-husband (which is off but that's okay).

One of my favorite moments in film is a high speed chase. Not a car chase, mind you, but a high-heel chase.I mean, of course, Roz Russell's  sprint after the buffoon of a sheriff in "His Girl Friday," as she literally pursues her story. Watch her gain speed like an Olympian -- in four-inch platform heels and a knee-length skirt. Watch the glorious climax, as she tackles him to the ground and pins him until he gives her the scoop.Hildy Johnson is far and away the most intelligent, sophisticated, accomplished and admired reporter of the many presented in this film -- and she is openly acknowledged as such. Not bad for a working girl in 1940.Something that might get lost in the film's sizzling dialogue and 80-mph pace is the news story that sets the plot into place -- the imminent hanging of Earl Williams. "His Girl Friday" has some interesting, subversive things to say about the death penalty. Not bad for a Hollywood comedy circa 1940.See this one, folks. Roz deserves it.

reviews.review_title: Without exception, the best version of The Front Page
reviews.content: Grant and Russell are comedy gold in this picture. They have an excellent comedic chemistry. Russell deliver's Hildy's lines so naturally it was as though MacArthur and Hecht wrote that dialog for her, specifically. and still maintained the grit of the original.I've never been a big fan of Ralph Bellamy but he plays the bright-eyed innocent with zest. And Grant is deliciously reprehensible as Walter Burns. I have trouble seeing what Hildy saw in him during their first marriage and that's as it should be.My only quibble is the inevitable 'woman gives up her own life for a man' scenario that is so much a part of 30's, 40's and 50's cinema post-code. Hildy is most alive when she's chasing the story and Russell looks a touch uncomfortable playing the 'little woman' moments. Less believable.All in all the best of the film versions.

This film was a solid all around film. the dialogue, comedy and premise make this movie relatable and appealing. The character dynamics alone are enough to keep the movie afloat, and the comedy is what keeps you wanting more.

reviews.review_title: A Must Watch for Every Cinema Lover
reviews.content: This movie is written so fantastically! With constant witty quips and lightning fast dialogue, the film never drags. The story is somehow able to match the pace of the quick dialogue as well, and that's nothing but praiseworthy. Seriously, hats off to everyone involved, it just gripped me the whole way through.

Fair warning: Use subtitles! They talk really fast.There are certainly a lot of campy moments and a couple of one-liners that elicit a PC "Eeeeeesh"...but not as many as I expected for an 80-year-old movie. It's actually surprisingly relevant: ineffectual police, gun violence, strained race relations, street protests, corrupt politicians. It's ostensibly a comedy; Grant and Russell do have great chemistry. But at the same time, the major question of the movie (released in 1940!) is whether or not a woman (a divorcée at that) wants to forego her passion for her profession or become a mother. And while the sheriff is a buffoon is cahoots with the mayor, their willingness to kill a man for political gain speaks to a level of corruption we've all to expect from our elected officials. Then there is a suicide attempt from a woman who's reputation has been ruined by unscrupulous newspaper reporters. While some of the technicalities have changed, much about "His Girl Friday" remains an acerbic parody of American society.

Originally I found "His Girl Friday" to be somewhat boring and definitely slow. I didn't think it was really funny or anything special at all. However by the end of the movie my opinions changed. I ended up loving the plot and I loved the constant bickering between all the characters mostly with the leads. Grants acting was excellent I'm starting to believe he just doesn't make a bad film. The editing was done well, the sound was good even though there really wasn't any over the top effects besides the shootout. I really liked the way the movie finished because the whole time I was wondering if they would end up getting back together or not. This turned out to be a simple, enjoyable movie even with the slow start and I would recommend it to any Grant or "screwball" fan.

The actors speak so fast you'll wonder if it's physiologically possible to do so. Based on Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur's hit play The Front Page, it's an incredibly cynical but extremely funny story. Nobody is very interested in Williams the killer or the details of his crime, only in its context as relates to them. The reporters want a scoop, the Mayor and Chief want the black vote, the Governor wants to be popular, the girlfriend wants to be noticed, Hildy wants the rush from beating out everyone else. From my viewpoint it's a stinging indictment of newshounds (and as relevant as ever today) but Hawks was a pragmatist and he plays it as a nutty comedy as everyone scrambles over everyone else fishing for the best angle. Screwball comedies of sexual dynamics and goofy situations were big in the late thirties and early forties, with films like It Happened One Night, Bringing Up Baby or The Philadelphia Story, and stars like Grant, Katharine Hepburn and Carole Lombard made their reputations with them. If they have one major attraction, it's the leading ladies' potential to let rip and Russell does not disappoint, with a fantastic ear-chewing swaggering tour-de-force performance as she out-shouts and out-mugs a very funny Grant, a sort of acting equivalent of a headbanging hard rock guitar solo. Bellamy, as the hopelessly out-of-his-depth nice guy, heads a great support cast full of nutjobs (such as Billy Gilbert as the doofus delivering the pardon), all of whom are obviously having a whale of a time.

reviews.review_title: Will keep you occupied for the entirety, that's for sure
reviews.content: Characterized by the constant bombardment of rapid-paced dialogue and ceaseless chain of events throughout the movie, it's hard to say that this is a bad movie from a production standpoint. Although it highlights the work of the scriptwriters, many parts of the dialog, especially towards the beginning, feels bland and uninteresting, which might disserve its purpose as a comedy. Plot-wise, although understandable for a 1940s film restricted by traditional values, a plot that a manipulative, abusive man can get away with his schemes and that a woman, regardless of professionalism, would submit to Stockholm syndrome is always a despicable sight to watch. The issues of the characters are the same from the beginning till the end, which present more of an irony than a comedy. Unrecommendable.

reviews.review_title: Okay Film, Just Not For ME
reviews.content: I think it was shot well, I just didn't really enjoy the themes. For a movie that tries to play itself as a screwball comedy, it pushes a dramatic agenda that doesn't do the film justice, and I found a few plot holes that I didn't necessarily understand, like the end decision of the main character. I also found the killer's dialog throughout the film cringey, and I didn't find the film "funny", but I can see the appeal for the time and the dedicated fans of it today. Overall, it was an okay film, even though I'm pointing out the negatives, wouldn't watch again.

This slapstick comedy really was a truly incredible film. His Girl Friday was a very well done film in all aspects including acting, cinematography, and editing. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell really did an incredible job. I do agree with Gavin. O by saying that these characters sort of overshadowed all the other characters. One of my favorite scenes with these two is the scene in the office when they are fighting back and forth and Rosalind starts talking like an auctioneer while Grant carries on. Thought that was very humorous. A cinematic element I really enjoyed was the way the camera always went through the office. You can see the camera would follow the character all through the office to show how busy and hectic people are working. It really gave you a sense and feel of the setting. Overall, this is one of the best films from this era I have seen by far.

reviews.review_title: Fast pace, fast talking film you need to see.
reviews.content: This film by Howard Hawks was brilliant. The characters were believable in the sense that they seemed exactly what you would expect from Newspapermen(and women) and balanced each other well. The movie went by fast and people could argue that it went by too quick but I would disagree. The director did it perfectly. The fast paced film showed the life of a reporter and how those who weren't a part of that world would get swept to the side but if it was your world you would thrive. The camera didn't move much with interesting camera angles and such but it did a good job of zooming in and out and showing the entire scene where certain characters were concerned. The by far best part of the good use of the camera was when Hildy and Walter were talking on the phone and it would swap back and forth. It didn't do it in a way that would make you dizzy but in a way that gave you a good picture of what was happening and of the conversation. The actors all helped because even though things would happen really fast you could understand them. The film wouldn't have been successful without the cast they used because they really helped bring the feel of the film to life and in the mist of all the confusion they made it clear through organized chaos. The movie was fast paced with fast talking and would have multiple conversations going at a time. It was great how the director could capture the conversations and the most important parts. The film gave a great portrayal of the journalism world, corruption within a government, and (yes cheesy but it was part of the film) a quick but accurate view of working men and women getting caught up in their jobs causing them to neglect their loved ones. It showed lying and sarcasm, and so much between the lines that swept the viewer. I would recommend this movie and am definitely going to watch it again in fear I have missed things. It was brilliantly done with characters, accurate portrayal of things, and the camera work limited though it was.

reviews.review_title: His Girl Friday(1940) is an excellent comedy
reviews.content: His Girl Friday is very fast paced. You may even need to play it in slow motion to be able to fully comprehend the lines that are spoken. The actors really must have worked hard in order to talk that fast. Hildy Johnson was married to Walter Burns but their marriage burned out as quick as they talked. The fast paced talking and changing story convinces us that this movie is about journalists. One of its messages is that the media has a great effect on the government good or bad. This is shown when there is a manhunt for a fugitive who is supposed to be hanged the next day. He escaped and somehow the journalists heard he was in a house across town where he used to live. The police used the rifle squad to try and take him down but in reality he hadn't even left the block. The escape is a panic manufactured by the media. And the media portrayed him as a homicidal maniac. Also this man was obviously mentally unstable but due to politics they had to make an example of him. The movie is hilarious throughout keeping it moving as fast as possible. His Girl Friday is a very good fast paced comedy movie that never stops its flow.

"His Girl Friday" directed by Howard Hawks is a pretty get screwball comedy/drama of the 1940's, Much better than others of its time period. However I believe that classic movies just aren't built to captivate the audiences of today. It was very hard for me to stay sucked into the screenplay.But I will give credit where credit is due. This is one of Howard Hawks better films, far better than some of his other productions. "His Girl Friday" is actually a great film to sit and watch if you enjoy black and white films and the occasional cheesy joke mixed in with screwball comedies.It's just not my cup of Tea.

This movie is vastly overrated and for a so called "classic" I'm disappointed. |The plot itself, the idea of a woman wanting to go from a top reporter, outstanding in her field, to a homemaker is actually unrealistic. Considering the feminist movements in the early-mid 1900s, this movie can come across as a misguided attempt to suppress feminists. The love interest, Walter, is manipulative and crass, and there is no reasons at all for Hildy to have changed her mind at the end, save for a wild stretch for a classic rom com ending. The rapid fire dialogue is annoying at best.

The movie His Girl Friday was probably one of the best black and white films I have seen.I Thought it was crazy how Hildy, Bruce (Hildy's fiancé), and Walter (Hildy's Ex- Husband) all went out to dinner together. They all seemed to talk to each other just fine without any fighting which surprised me. I liked how this movie was fast paced because it really made the movie come to life. The seriousness of the movie made it very suspenseful. The seriousness had me hooked to watch the rest of the movie.Right from the beginning I knew that Hildy was going to miss her ex-husband because they communicated very well, and worked together to try and make the paper the next big thing. What shocked me was when Walter kissed Hildy before she was "leaving" to go to Albany. It shocked me because Hildy was supposed to get married the very next day.The only thing that I didn't like about this movie was that it was hard to understand in the beginning of the movie since there was so much going on.on a side note, why did Hildy change her hat after the first scene from a striped to a solid color hat?I would rate this movie a 9 out of 10

I Enjoyed the humor of the time. Really tame by todays standards but its like going back into a time portal for the thoughts and feelings of the time. The comedy falls in line with "The Code" era nothing too racy but I found myself laughing when Walter hadn't learned his lesson by the end of the film. I noticed the High Key Lighting in most scenes involving Russel. Nice mix between the screwball comedy element and the serious endeavor Russel embarks on. Overall thought the film was decent. Cinematography wise seemed very basic but that's to be expected of the time. Use of dissolve in and out between scenes.

This movie was simply great, I couldn't really even pick out anything wrong with it that really stood out to me. Despite the lack of ball-busting humor, the outright chaos and confusion kept my eyes glued to the screen! I was most impressed with the complete unpredictability that ensued, which is very hard to come by. Without giving too much away, the entirety of the time the camera spent in the Press Room was complete chaos to the point where it just because ridiculously hilarious. Considering how this movie was produced in 1940, I still can't help but think about the volumes that it speaks about today's press. I mean, let's be honest, it is still an utter mess! My last thought has to be about the love story. I don't want to give too much away so I'll just leave you with this: This love story was a doomed mess from the start, I don't know what Hildy was even thinking! But as a female myself, Walter Burns is pretty damn convincing.

After one time watching this movie I can officially say that my list of favorites has grown by one. Its a fast paced and a lot of action is packed into a very short amount of time, every time I thought I knew what was going to happen next, something completely different, something I definitely wouldn't have expected, would happen. This movie is a great example of the type of comedy I like best. Hildy and Walter are my new favorite movie couple. They're both just super intense, amazing at what they do, and by the end they both have a pretty decent idea of what they want. Watching the movie its easy to tell they probably aren't great for each other, but I can't help but hope that after the end titles, the relationship would have worked (if it were a real relationship). As much as I loved Hildy and Walter, I did feel really bad for Bruce in the end. It looked like he and Hildy would have had a good thing.

His Girl Friday is one of the more intelligently written movies I have seen in a long time. Each character is well portrayed and I applaud the actors for being able to film each scene without laughing at each other. The jokes are intelligent and hold a deeper, more hilarious meaning should you have the knowledge of the censorship code from the 19-30's onward. I particularly enjoyed how the romance of the plot, while likely intended to be the main focus of the movie, often got put on the back burner in favor of the mystery of Earl Williams (a far more interesting story to be told anyway). However, Walter Burns and Hildy Johnson were partners in crime until the very end, a pair that while they had their disagreements, were meant for each other.

This is a classic film starring Carey Grant, on top of the subtle comedy that he naturally uses in his films, it portrays a very alive romance with a funny spin on it, most of the humor is old fashioned but it still is pretty fun even for the nowadays. the actors are very convincing in this film as well some of the movies of the period are not exactly the most convincing but the lead roles in this one do a very good job of showing consistent portrayal of their characters.

This film was fun to watch. There was always something going on and the comedy was thrown in perfectly. Even though you kind of knew that nothing was ever going to go easy for any of the characters, the fun of the movies was to watch all the hilarious ideas and schemes work for a bit and then come crashing down.

"His Girl Friday", (1940) is a classic screwball comedy, made to display romance and laughter. The pace of this film is very fast pace, making it hard to follow and grasp the humor. Although it is quick, the dialogue is very modern and well done. The dialogue adds the humor to the film, in addition to the speed of the film making it as humorous as it was. The editing of this film was done very well, and isn't choppy, which makes following the film a little easier. The casting of the film was also very well done, and the characters felt as if they were people not actors. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell were a good screen pair, and acted very well together making the film more seamless and more exciting to watch seeing that they had a real connection. Despite the quickness of this film, the quality of the content and the aspects that contributed to the film made it a success.

reviews.review_title: You can't take the journalist out of the girl.
reviews.content: Witty and fast-paced, this movie was really a delight to watch! Having never seen this movie before it was a blast watching Walter's plans unfold as he tried to keep Hildy at his side where she truly belongs. The interactions between characters were perfectly portrayed and the plot never became bogged down in semantics. It was a good, light-hearted movie that I would not mind watching again.

The movie started off really slow with Walter and Hildey arguing for about 10 mins straight in the movie. The plot picked up so fast it was almost hard to keep up with it. Walter was being motivated to get his wife back was an understatement and as much I wanted to doubt him, his plan was falling into place like a domino effect. This movie definitely caught by surprise with the pace it was going at towards the middle of the moving. It went from almost having me fall asleep to keeping me on my toes wanting to know what was going to happen next.

The title His Girl Friday is quite ironic because a girl Friday represents a servant; but the thing is Hildy is the brains behind the newspaper and either as smart or smarter then Walter.
When Walter finally meets Bruce he uses Bruce's innocence and kindness to try and get his way by sabotaging Hildy and Bruce's marriage.
During the jail break scene of Earl Williams the director does a very good job a grabbing the attention of the audience. He does so by loud siren noises and while the reporters are on the phone you can see the intensity of the scene by the camera constantly switching from reporter to reporter.

reviews.review_title: You'll love every moment of this classic comedy!
reviews.content: It's a shame that a movie of this caliber did not receive an Oscar (or any nominations).  It's clearly one of the best movies ever made.  Although the comedy genre doesn't get much respect, this film showed that there is nothing greater than a great comedy.  My advice would be to see it ... then you'll want to see it again ... and again!

This is a great old comedy about a reporter and his ex-wife who used to work for him, coming to tell her ex that she is getting re-married. He decided to come up with a scheme to lure her back in to working for the paper, because he knows that she cannot resist a good story.I found this to really funny and enjoyable to watch. Cary Grant is simply hilarious when his character and his ex-wife are arguing. It becomes even more entertaining when he goes out to lunch with his ex and her new husband to be. Cary Grant's character is cocky and very witty, and I was truly laughing out loud in all of his scenes. The story started to drag a little in the middle of the film, and I will admit that I started to get a little bored. Regardless, I continued to watch and there were more laughs to come at the end of the film.Overall, it is worth watching and is a fantastic film for its time. If you are in the mood for an old romantic comedy that has you laughing, definitely tune into "His Girl Friday."

What an awesome movie this was such a strangely dark and strangely funny movie at the same time. The acting was incredible everyone in the cast played their part so well. Cary Grant was incredible he is so cool and so quick at the same time. I thought the movie had a really good story and it was surprisingly kind of gritty. I am surprised this is in the screwball comedy category because I think it is too good to be considered a comedy. I love the dialogue and the acting it is so quick but if you pay attention you can still catch everything they are saying. The film gives you a window into the lives of reporters back then and it shows us the lovable vultures that they are. Overall see this movie its worth it.

The first thing I noticed when I started watching this movie was that everyone talked very fast! Once you get used to it, it sort of adds a comic touch to movie. It wasn't may favorite screwball comedy I've seen but it definitely has humor. I thought the scene when Hildy and Walter were in his office was funny because they would jump back and forth from sincerely talking about their history and then the next second they start yelling and fighting with each other. Part of you starts to feel bad for Bruce because he loves Hildy and keeps trying to get them off to Albany but Hildy is so caught up in the newspaper business and spending a lot of time with her ex-husband, but at the same time when the movie comes to an end and Walter and Hildy decide to get back together you are happy for them because it it like they are meant to be.

The film starts off with Hildy returning to her job at The Morning Post, only to tell her boss, Walter, that she is quitting. The funny part is that her boss just happens to be her ex-husband, which creates an interesting environment throughout the rest of the movie. Hildy originally wants a divorce from Walter because she wants a more homey life where she can settle down and have children. When she returned she also revealed that she was getting married the following day and her fiancé, Bruce, who was an insurance agent was with her. Throughout the movie Walter comes up with ways, by using Hildy's love of being a reporter, to elongate her stay.This is definitely a fast paced movie with a lot going on all at once. It was interesting to see the screwball comedy that was used throughout the movie. I highly recommend this film. You are guaranteed to laugh.

reviews.review_title: Going in blind will let this movie have its max effect!
reviews.content: "His Girl Friday," is one of those movies that i could never quite catch on t.v. from start to end. But, having finally seen it in all its' glory, I can say it's definitely worth a watch. Carey and Russel are both dynamic actors who really play their characters fully here, as always. While they both fit the roles they were given perfectly; I do feel that together their performances sort of tug at the limelight one way or the other in a number of scenes. This, at least to me; kind of muted their respective charisma's; at least until the second half. By the time the second half comes around, the characters gel together much more seamlessly. Having come into this with little idea of what to expect; I was pleasantly surprised when the climax of the movie made its' appearance. The moments where his 'Con-man,' persona comes to light are hilarious; his talent to make an innocent bystander feel guilty for something that Carey himself has done wrong is pure delight. Highly recommend going into this as blind as possible!

reviews.review_title: A little fast paced and annoying
reviews.content: Going into this movie I thought it was going to be a lot like the movie My Man Godfrey, and it was just ramped up about ten times. Not everything about this movie was that annoying, I did find myself laughing at some parts and it flowed very well but in my opinion the majority of it was just loud and annoying. I hated when they would all be talking very loudly over each other and it gave me a more unamusing vibe than an amusing one. I also found Cary Grants character to be just annoyingly selfish throughout this movie and really didn't care for his wife or what she wanted and would only be satisfied if he got his way. But what made that situation so unbelievable is how selfish Rosalind Russell's character was as well and truthfully I believe they would've been perfect for each other if they would just wake up and smell the coffee for two seconds! Overall not a horrible movie but I believe if they just slowed it down a little and mad the characters a little more likable or maybe just one of the more likable I would've enjoyed it more.

This movie is very well done and written, it is just so fast paced where i felt like i missed a lot. Really enjoyed the film though, i loved the strong female lead. It was super cool how the director weaved in two different story lines into the movie. The love triangle of Hildy, Walter, and Bruce. I was a little disappointed in the ending as i was hoping Hildy would've turned down Walter. I guess it wouldn't be a screwball comedy if they didn't end up together in the end though.

I wasn't really sure how I would feel about this type of comedy movie since I had never watched one before, but to my surprise I was actually found it very funny. I can definitely see why it's considered a classic. I really enjoyed the how fast paced the dialogue was between the characters, I think that added to the comedy of the scenes.

What I like best about this film is the strong female lead. What I don't like about this film is that she ends up getting saved by a man. That's really my only annoyance with the film, the main character's ex-husband is manipulative and controlling in such a way that isn't overt but almost humorous - that crafty way of presenting male dominance upsets me to no end. Why did he have to rope her back in? It was as though the director only wanted the audience to think that the woman was clever and independent while simultaneously making a statement about how the ambitions of women cannot go anywhere (literally and figuratively) without a man. And I had so much hope for the film, I really did enjoy it until the end.
Besides that, the acting from everyone was very good as well as the writing. Those plot points where very well put together, so many twists!

This is exactly what it was meant to be...a screwball comedy! It started out hilarious and finished the same way. This was such a fun movie from beginning to end, as well as funny! The chemistry between the two leading actors, Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell is unreal. The pair made this romantic comedy so believable and made me feel like everything on the screen was really happening.
 
The movie's dialog moved very quickly, but was easily understood. The visual cues helped to effortlessly move the story along in case dialog was missed or misinterpreted by the viewer. The filming was very clean, meaning the overall look was crisp. Also, the background effects/noises in this film were nicely done and very realistic. This movie is a great one to watch, the filming was excellent and there's never a dull moment!

The movie is directed by Howard Hawks. the movie is good if you like a comedy, drama between ex lovers that were married to one another. Rosalind Russell play's Hildy Johnson and Walter Burns played by Cary Grant. Rosalind Russell character plays reports at her ex husband's newspaper. but she shows up to tell him that she is quitting the newspaper to get married to Bruce Baldwin and start a family also move to Albany.Bruce Baldwin is played by Ralph Bellamy. Walter Burns gives Hildy Johnson a offer she cannot refuse by telling her to write about Earl Williams and how he was going to get hanged for the crime he committed. he was going to pay her big money for doing the story but he was really try to make her miss her train and make her say their with him. beacues he still loves her and does not want her to leave with her new man. then eventually they work together and her fiance gets annoyed by waiting for her and leave with out her. To go back to Albany.Walter Burns and Hildy Johnson fall in love with one another again when they are working together. 
The movie is fast pace so if you can't keep up with fast paced talking and it could get confusing at times if you can't understand the dialect of what they are saying and if you don't like intense but funny armaments between the to main characters then you will not like tis film but if you like a love triangle between her and the two men.Walter Burns trying to take back and Hildy Johnson away from Bruce Baldwin throughout the movie.

reviews.review_title: So Much Wit in an hour and a half
