reviews.content: The first thing I noticed about this movie was it had a strong lead female role, which i feel like wasn't as popular of a choice back then as it was now. Rosalind Russell plays Hildy Johnson, a popular, respected and successful journalist who decides to leave the journalist life behind and settle down with her new husband in Albany, NY. Cary Grant plays Walter Burns, Hildy's boss and ex-husband who cant bear to see her leave the company. Throughout his numerous attempts to change Hildys mind, I realized how extremely manipulative Walter can be if he needs to. He is outwardly very charming but always has an arterial motive. I was also amused by the banter between the journalists, always going back and forth . They treated all things as just a potential story to the point that they ask the mayor to reschedule a hanging so they can have a headline about it. in fact, all of the dialogue was interesting sue to it being so fast. I even looked it up and the director wanted to break the record for most words said in a movie, which really shows. Nearly every conversation is a witty exchange of words that keeps you entertained, even though things happen very fast. I think this movie was very good, I just wish they talked a little slower at times

His girl Friday is very funny. Some of the lines in this film had me crying from laughter. I love the way the actors and actresses delivered their lines. . I love how Rosalind Russell portrays her character. She's mean, fierce, but funny while doing so, and she means business. I think her acting is some of the best in the entire film. This movie is the definition of an early screwball comedy. Overall, I enjoyed this film a lot because it was funny.

This film was not as interesting as I hoped it would be. The scenery, costumes, cast, filming was all well. However, I felt this movie dragged a bit in the beginning middle and end. Some of it was over the top and not realistic. I didn't believe any woman would let a man put her through all that and be with him in the end. He was rude and obnoxious; speaking of the leading man and woman. It was all too much and just displayed a toxic relationship. This movie is just watchable. I don't start movies without finishing them and that's the only reason I seen the entire film.

His Girl Friday is an incredibly entertaining film with snappy dialogue that feels fast even for today, tongue in cheek jokes about what would soon become WWII, and jokes that, I will admit, would not likely get praised by modern audiences, but is still hilarious regardless.

Lively dialogue, great cast, zany story line adds up to brilliant entertainment
Don't miss this gem from a time where there were no mindless car chases and startling special effects.but it was the actors and actresses who held us spellbound through each scene.The old gentleman whom Walter mistakes for the fiancee adds real depth as in most of these exceptionally good comedolies from the 40's

reviews.review_title: His Girl Friday: Good but not Great
reviews.content: While I did get some enjoyment out of this film, I also felt that the pacing was a little slow and often not particularly interesting. It was neat to see that some of this film took place in my hometown on Albany, New York, and getting a look at the 1940's version of the city was very cool. The dynamic between Hildy and Bruce is very funny and seeing him obsess over her is a fun and engaging dynamic. The screwball comedy aspects were fun at times but I found many that didn't land for me which is where my disappointment with the movie lies. The ending is well executed, with the implication that the cycle will repeat all over again, and this was a high point of the movie for me. Overall however, I just didn't think many of the jokes landed, but it was still engaging enough to be worth the watch.

The movie is a very wonderful romance comedy. the movie is a little fast paced. the acting is wonderful.the lead characters like "Cary grant and Rosalind" is the perfect role for this movie.The movie provides us with the environment of a reporter. A girl is loved by her former fiancé but the man is loved with the news so the girl is ignored.The movie is about a man who do many tricks to get the love of his life.His Girl Friday successfully combines screwball romantic comedy with biting satire and no seams show it all in the stitching. It's a blueprint on how to do successful cinema comedy.Only the main characters focused in this film. the movie is always circled around the girl.The girl wants to stay a reporter but because of his former husband,she is trying to get away from all the reporting.But the feeling of reporting never goes and still she loves the man.

reviews.review_title: A newspaper editor tries everything to win back his ex wife. While getting the story of the century of course.
reviews.content: This film is a great film for the time period. It is very fast paced and requires the viewer to try actively pay attention in order to keep up. The fast paced and witty dialogue is a rarity today and is very funny and enjoyable. However, this may be one of the few times where I would have preferred a non-traditional, sadder Hollywood ending. The the suspense that builds during one of the final scenes in which the killer is hiding in the desk, would have really paid off if the squabbles ended in an accidental killing of the insane killer instead of everything working out. Although that may sound gruesome, it would have been a perfect way to resolve the petty bickering between the characters during such an intense scene as it would have put the whole situation in perspective. I guess that would have made it a different film. The film we do have is still very enjoyable, even to a modern audience.

Starting off, I was entranced by how well they portrayed a self- reliant and determined female lead. The entire film covers the controversy, and hilarity, of a women working for her ex-husband while her fiancé aimlessly attempts to understand the situationsThe film does well with providing sustenance towards plot while still managing to remain witty and sarcastic between characters. Cary Grant does his part as the witty ex-husband and keeps things interesting by providing obstacles the entire flick.Another aspect I was fond of was Rosalind Russell's female lead. We are introduced to her walking among her peers and giving direction when needed and, her later actions, show her heart is in her work.In essence, the film was outstanding and I would recommend it to anyone who is looking for an interesting screwball comedy.

There was a lot going on in this movie. I liked it though, interesting how there was two story lines going on at the same time. An ex husband trying to get his wife back and a crime scene trying to be unraveled at the same time. I liked how there was a strong female lead. Sometimes it was a little hard to understand because she would talk really fast, but those were just little details that weren't too important. Overall I thought it had a great plot and it definitely kept me watching.

This was a sort of a confusing movie. I felt like half the film was a set up towards the fiancé. Once I finished the movie I thought what was going on?. You know the term ladies man well Hildy was quite the flirt with the men. Honestly her beauty really attracted every man even her ex husband. I think the movie used a lot of unnecessary characters that sort of didn't correlate with the story overall I enjoyed it. The movie wasn't a real screwball comedy like "My man Godfrey" that's going to probably be my favorite. There were a few action scenes that would've looked great with color some scenes were a bit dark.

A woman spends her last day as a news writer, before moving upstate and getting married, documenting the controversy surrounding a local death row victim. Meanwhile, her ex husband, and the newspaper's editor, does everything in his power to win her back. It's a pretty interesting and rather original set-up. The plot is very busy and fast-paced, most likely to mirror to chaos of a newsroom. The humor is also very quick, consisting of witty, conversational one-liners and wise remarks, so some of the jokes can definitely go over your head. Regardless, the film is hilarious. My favorite line is when one man asks another, "you always carry an umbrella? Rubbers too I hope," while motioning to his rubber rain boots. A lot of the humor still holds up today. His Girl Friday, while surely comedic, is also a satirical look into the press at that time. You can tell how corrupt the industry, or at least this company, is. The lengths some of the reporters go to get a good story is absurd. I really enjoyed this film and would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh.

I believe that the film His Girl Friday was a very enjoyable screwball comedy. The film was very lively and entertaining, while moving at a faster pace but keeping the audience interested. The relationship in the movie is that Hildy Johnson has an ex husband, Walter Burns, and she is now engaged to Bruce Baldwin. I believe the height of comedy in this movie, for myself is how even though Hildy has harsh feelings towards Walter and has moved on, she still knows him very well. For example, she has Bruce give her all of their money to hold on to, and when she is on the phone with him tells him to put his check in his hat. Later, Bruce realizes hat his wallet among other things were missing. This proves that Hildy was right and still knows her ex husbands character. This also shows how smart and independent she can be, which is a very positive outlook on women, especially during that time period.

reviews.review_title: All stories are just love stories
reviews.content: Well, not all but a lot of them are love stories. This one is just a little more romantic. Of all the screwball comedies I've seen, this one is my favorite. I think it's much more tasteful, in humor than many of the other films in the same genre. The "slapstick" comedy is more toned down than say in My Man Godfrey. The acting/writing is eloquent too, this can be attributed to the fantastic performance by Cary Grant.

reviews.review_title: The best of the three Front Page movies
reviews.content: This version, a remake of the original by Pat O'Brien and Adolphe Menjou, is the best of the three versions of this play adapted to the screen. (The third starred Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau and is nearly as good.)It's an absolute hoot. And I've seen it probably two dozen times. It's better than potato chips. I can't just watch one scene. Whenever it's on I'm hooked for the duration.The snappy patter, split-second timing and overlapping dialogue is enough to make you want the script for re-reading after the credits have run.They don't make 'em like this any more.

reviews.review_title: His Girl Friday: A Classic Screwball
reviews.content: Definitely the epitome of screwball comedy is this film, His Girl Friday. With the arguing about randomness turning into a cringe-y bit of humor, it is a basic slapstick comedic film. Back when the only way to make a funny film at the time was to poke fun at "the Code" in a fourth wall sense, and does this film do just that. This film has you laughing at just 10 minutes into the film and has you laughing until just about the very end of the film. Has a basic but decent story to it, nothing too intricate but also not dull in a sense. It is a bit lackluster in the cinematic aspect but the screwball isn't about that; it's about the comedic story which this film has done very well. Very recommended on watching the film if you need a good laugh for the night.

Howard Hawk's film His Girl Friday is a great screwball comedy with a lot of twist and turns. The small remarks throughout the film are very funny and keep the viewer intrigued. Even though Hildy says she wants to leave to go to Albany she always gets pulled back into the story, but what she doesn't realize is she is slipping away from Bruce. Ironically in the beginning of the film she wanted to get away from Walter but as the film goes on she keeps getting drawn closer. Through out the whole movie you expect Hildy to be with Bruce but the last minute she ends up with Walter. Even though a lot of the movie seemed to be about the newspaper story about the murderer the underlying love story truly pulls it all together. Hawk's did a great job with this film and it was very enjoyable.

His Girl Friday is a witty, fast talking, story that takes an original route. Two characters with a shared past, experience the limits of their professions as well as their love. Sometimes it only takes a life experience to make you realize what was meant to be. Cary Grant, and Rosalind Russel do an great job personifying their characters, making the film feel authentic and their characters Walter and Hildy, convincing and endearing. Although the plot isn't the strongest, nor the most engaging to the audience, the protagonists as well as the supporting cast carry the movie to the level of notoriety it holds today.

An imaginative and hilarious adaptation of the play `The Front Page', this film combines fast-paced, overlapping, witty dialogue with long master shots that showcase the incredible talent of the entire cast. The action never slows down as you are perched on the edge of your seat throughout the entire film. You actually care about what happens to these dynamic, three-dimensional characters- they feel like old friends.

I watched this film and overall I enjoyed it. I love good, quick, sarcastic banter. This movie has a lot of it. Subtle barbs between characters and under the breath remarks. That's more amusing to me than physical comedy. Rosalind Russell is phenomenal in this film as Hildy. Cary Grant did a good playing the character Walter - Walter himself was pretty unappealing. He was manipulative, inconsiderate and narcissistic. I had a really hard time rooting for them to get back together. I am not even sure if you're supposed to be happy for them? Overall I enjoyed the other story arch happening in the film much more than their reconciliation. The supporting cast is full of enjoyable characters that definitely lend to coloring the settings of the film. For really only having a few different locales/room the movie doesn't seem boring or claustrophobic. It's a very well made movie.

One of the best written movies ever for dialogue; every talks on top of each other and that adds to the general mayhem and fun of the movie; excellent acting and comic timing; remakes of this movie only show how stilted dialogue can be and how unrealistic it is to real life!

reviews.review_title: His Girl Friday holds up over time.
reviews.content:
His Girl Friday is a well-made and well-acted screwball. The filming, editing lighting, and sound of this movie are very well done. The dialogue is very fast paced, but done to perfection. However, I think what makes it stand up over time, as with many other screwball comedies from the time, is the fact that the overly dramatic acting of the time actually works quite well with this style. The characters aren't trying to be dead serious, so their over the top nature adds to the somewhat mocking nature of the genre. I also think the strength of Hildy as a character helped to make the movie more enjoyable and believable. She wasn't constantly fainting or acting helpless like many female characters of the time, which seems pretty unnatural in modern times.
While most screwball comedies are meant to be just that, comedies, I found His Girl Friday to be more sad than funny. While there were plenty of funny jokes and exchanges, the underlying mocking of the callousness of the press seems all to relevant nowadays and I couldn't help but root for Hildy to get out and leave with Bruce. Instead of finding her constantly getting sucked back in by Walter funny and comical, I found it disheartening. Perhaps I am taking the movie too seriously. Nevertheless, the movie still holds up well and I would recommend it.

reviews.review_title: The film that got me into films
reviews.content: I first saw HGF one Sunday night on C4 and I was about 14. It blew my mind, the speed of the dialogue, the contempory nature of the topics, this film had not aged at all. I recently saw it in our local Cinema and it only gets better. There is so much going on and stairway sam is a character strait out of British lad mag land. Sombody said the true test of a film is that it gets better and more relevant with age. This is certainly true here. Oh and yes it is still very FUNNY.

Absolutely hilarious film. I strongly recommend to anyone who loves old screwball comedies. Walter and Hildy have the strangest relationship which you root for the entire movie (at least I did). When you're born to be something you can't fight your true feelings. Hildy as fighting her wants to be a reporter to live a normal life but something kept pulling her back in after she found out concrete evidence that an innocent man was being convicted. The way they filmed this movie with high key lighting really makes it jump out at you and makes you want to keep watching.

reviews.review_title: You got to be kidding me !!
reviews.content: This film had its ups and downs. It was a comic for sure ! But I was upset about the fact that She had divorced Walter and decided to start a brand new life with her soon to be husband Bruce but then Walter had to LITERALLY RUIN everything that they had planned together. Poor Bruce did not know what had hit him. I do not like Walter for doing such a thing. They got a divorce for a reason ! But then decided to get married again at the end of the movie... ohhh how well there second marriage will work out! geeeshhhh.

I have never watched a more fast-pace movie than "His Girl Friday". Like all screwball comedies, this film relies on witty dialog and sarcasm, but I have never seen it pulled off so fluidly and quick as this. Whereas some screwball comedies rely on making social critiques to give their films an edge, such as "My Man Godfrey", "His Girl Friday" wins the audience with top notch comedy and wit.The setting of a newspaper publisher is perfect for the frantic speed and tone of the whole movie, and the relationship between Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell is all the film needs to drive it forward and is premise everyone can relate to. This is by far my favorite screwball comedy.

Really funny, but underneath lies a dark movie.Everybody loves how deliciously FAST this movie is. The plot head-snaps in every scene. Wit and pacing are tops, particularly when they are on the phone, two different conversations going at once. But the best parts are when it slows down and stops. Such as when Walter (Cary Grant) admits to Hildy (Rosalind Russell) that she "took the wind out of my sails" -- that never happens! Or when Hildy says "nevermind..." and just leaves it there.Hildy owns this show; Rosalind Russell upstages Cary Grant, likely the only time that occurred in any of his movies. She says intensely biting things about journalists -- basically that they are nobody's friend. At one point she demonstrates this to a room full of them, and they are caught speechless. Yet the excitement of getting the next story is something she cannot deny.Kudos to the supporting players. The speed of the dialogue would be insufferable without the slow-talking straight man Bruce (Ralph Belamy) and "innocent" hapless murderer (Porter Hall), who wait their turn to speak.

The use of overlapping dialogue in certain scenes within the news areas really made the movie feel very realistic. This film was one of the first to utilize overlapping dialogue and it worked really well. Alongside the overlapping, the fast paced dialogue moved the story and character development along in a coherent way that allowed us to see what each character was like & how they behaved. Also, the fast paced dialogue made certain parts of the movie very funny. The characters skipping around in conversations allowed them to quickly say comedic things that worked well with the situations. Some of the characters did seem to be kind of annoying and unlikeable, but I overlooked it because the movie was funny and enjoyable because of how those characters were portrayed.

I did not like this film to much, I thought it was a outreach of comedy. Sometimes the comedy just wasn't there and I felt like the main character played by Cary Grant was just not the most entertaining. The only other comedy movie like this I watched was My man Godfrey, is this movie I felt happy and even when the tone was a little bit darker it was still funny in nature, however in this film I felt like the banter didn't work to well and most of the time it was just back and forth nonsense. This corny movie could not make it today, it is just over rated and I am disappointed I sat through this whole thing.

His girl Friday is one of those movies that is made to just make you laugh and nothing more. I found this film to be very enjoyable and also has great performances from Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell, who I believe was actually more entertaining than Grant. The writing is quick witted and fun. The story is something that is in all screwball comedies at the time, very paint by the numbers. Overall, I enjoyed watching this movie and think it is worth a watch to anyone who loves comedy.

When he hears that his ex-wife, Hildy Johnson, wants to get married again, Walter Burns pretends to be okay. But Walter isn't okay. He wants Hildy back and tries to get her during the movie. But Hildy has moved on. Throughout the movie, Hildy proves how smart and witty she is. For example, when she had Bruce give her all of their money to hold onto. And later when shes on the phone with him, she tells him to put his check in his hat. Later, Bruce realizes how he's missing some thing, including his wallet! Hildy knows that Walter had something to do with it. This shows how she still knows her ex husband very well and is a very smart woman. Throughout the movie, Hildy proves how intelligent and talented women really are. This is very important, especially during that time period.

I didn't find the story line to be too interesting. What I did find enjoyable though, was the things Walter said. He's quite funny. As smart as Hildy is, she let Walter walk all over her, when she walked all over Bruce. I guess that shows that Walter and Hildy are pretty alike. The film all in all didn't make much of an impression on me. I found myself getting bored a few times. However, it was not bad. I was interested to see what exactly Hildy would do, even though it was pretty easy to guess that she'd end up with Walter. It was also interesting to see where the "criminal" would end up, and I was not expecting the girl to throw herself out of a window.

reviews.review_title: I am unsure how this movie works its magic...
reviews.content:
A story of love, comedy, action, suspense & tragedy. All told in one busy day! The story is set in the chaotic world of newspaper reporting. Ms Russell's character is desperately trying to leave behind her career as an extremely talented 'Girl Friday' and to embrace her future as a doting & loving wife. To do so, she must outsmart her cunning, quick-witted ex-husband (Gary Grant) who, as her manager, assigns her to report on the crime story of the century.
To stay and report the story could save a man's life, but the delay could cost her her future happy home life with her new honest & simple fiancé.Cary Grant is at his finest. It's easy to get swept up in the story and invested in the Characters. Well worth a watch if you enjoyed 'Intolerable Cruetly' (movie). A fast-paced comedy.

I have always been a fan of screwball comedies and this one did not disappoint. I found both Hildy and Walter constantly make me laugh throughout this film and it was much more than just a comedy with a great plot as well. the lighting in this film was very intense at almost all times and made it very easy to see the expressions on each actors face. This also saved the film from feeling over dramatic at times. Many of the scenes in this movie were very long but I felt it was great content because of the comedy in the movie. The acting of Hildy was done brilliantly and I felt that this movie must have felt very empowering to women at the time because of what Hildy was capable of achieving in this movie. I also felt the camera work was fantastic in this movie. There were very slight movements but it was steady throughout the film and it always kept the main character in focus and in the center

reviews.review_title: Walter Burns defend her ex wife from getting married to Bruce who proposed Rosalind to live better life and having children
reviews.content: In the meantime, "His Girl Friday" its the movie that has many impacts to our society from the life of journalist to the "love". Carry Grant played as Walter Burns he doesn't want to leave his ex wife Rosalind Russell as Hildegard to get married to Mr. Bruce. Definitely can't happen to me either how can a man come to proposal to your ex wife. I have no idea if this can happen to real life, but its all about movie magic. Afterwards its a great movie and great story, director Howard Hawks did a great job. Eventually its a black and white movie but you can see everything clearly super cool. Finally love never end for those who love each other, Mr. Walter Burns dedicate to remarry Rosalind "Hildy" and going to Niagara fall for the honeymoon. "Extra there are money like Mr. Burns wants to sabotage your marriage plan please hide until you overcome"

I've noticed a pattern with the movies I've watched for my American Cinema class. They are all identical in execution to the movie we watch in class that week. "His Girl Friday" does not stray from this pattern at all. If anything, it reinforces it. The plot once again follows an unlikely couple, only this time both people are at least competent. No one is stupid to levels of annoyance except for the female's initial love interest. Despite the characters being more likable, the genre of the screwaball comedy is just so uninteresting to me, which severely hindered my enjoyment of this movie. Now don't get me wrong, I'm not saying it's a bad movie, but this sort of back and forth lighthearted comedy is not for me.

I found this film to be a wonderful film. It was an easy movie to watch. There were moments of humor, romance, action, and even some suspense. It had just about everything you could want in a movie. On top of that the female lead was strong-willed and was one of the best parts of the film. This would be a great film to watch if your not accustomed to black and white movies due to the range of genre the film has. There is something for everyone to enjoy.

reviews.review_title: How did they do that without music?
reviews.content: We have recently begun to view movies made before we were born. What a pleasant surprise. I had no idea how present-centric we were. There are so many delightful movies from the 40's and 50's. I would give anything to see a current movie with the kind of snappy dialogue that His Girl Friday had. It is also interesting to note the cultural norms of the day. Rosiland Russell plays a no nonsense reporter who is the equal of her former husband and newspaper editor, Cary Grant. The movie is interesting for the use of a "battle of the sexes" theme that is actually a courtship ritual for a woman who is a independent as Russell. But I was amazed at the use of the term picaninny to describe a black child. I was incredulous that there was absolutely no music to heighten the emotional scenes. Says a lot about directing and writing in those days.

Ever since I saw Cary Grant in one of his later films Charade with Audrey Hepburn, I have just loved him in every other role I have seen him in and His Girl Friday was no exception. This was a highly entertaining screwball comedy starred Cary Grant as the Morning Post Editor, Walter Burns and his ex-wife Hildy Johnson who was played by the lovely Rosalind Russell. Their bickering as ex-husband and wife was funny to watch and they had good chemistry. Only a former husband who still cared for his ex that much would go as far as burns did constantly throughout the movie getting Hildy's new husband to be thrown in jail and getting her to cover one last news story before she leaves the newspaper behind to become a housewife.

reviews.review_title: This movie is a classic screwball comedy film
reviews.content: This Screwball Comedy is really funny. I love the fact that Hildy has more power all the men in this movie. This movie is really fast paced and the diolouge is also very fast. There are so many little jokes in this movie, if you are not paying attention for a couple of seconds you are going to miss the humor. I had to re-watch this movie 2 times to fully understand every part in it. I was happy that I watched this movie 2 more times because I missed a lot of the little funny humor that is in it. This is an excellent screwball comedy for the Great Depression Era, you can see how most of the characters are middle class while Hildy is Extremely Wealthy. My favirote character was Bruce. Bruce is so nice but he gets played and used so many times by Hildey and Walter which is hilarious. Bruce doesn't understand that he is just being pushed around. Overall I liked this movie, the humor was truly great.

The comedy used in "His Girl Friday" still holds up today. Cary Grant's quick delivery and wit is a big reason that he's my favorite actor from this era. The way he delivers his lines so quickly while acknowledging everything that's happening in the room is masterful.Billy Gilbert's performance sort of steals the show in this film. While he's only on the screen for about five minutes, those five minutes are some of the funniest of the film. The way he looks at the other actors and how he lets everything go over is head is amazing. He really deserved more screen time in the film.The final scene of the film is great. Every actor in the film pops up in this scene. Once again Grant was a master. The way he talked on the phones really made one believe that he was having three conversations at the same time. The conversation he has with the woman on the phone is my favorite moment of the whole film. The comedic timing when he says "What did i say?" after she hangs up is gold.

The movie has very fast paced comedy with plot twists, fast dialogue and the classic love triangle. It also features a prominent female lead, Hildy who is trying to leave the paper business. Most of the comedy aspects of the film comes from Walter Burns, Hildy's ex husband, who does everything in his power to keep his ex wife from leaving with newly engaged Bruce Baldwin. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell were an incredible pair. Their on screen chemistry and wit seemed to play off each other perfectly.

This screwball comedy fits the criteria well and tells its story in a very engaging manner. The film opens up with our two main characters giving expository dialogue while speaking very fast. Normally, a film that has an exposition dump at the beginning only drags the story down, but this film keeps you enthralled in it because of how the characters speak and act. The movie then follows Hildy as she struggles to leave her old life as a reporter for a simpler one, while various gags ensue. The last half of this film is crazy, having many things going on at once. The press room having many telephones with many people talking on them at once nicely visualizes the chaos of everything. The ending, while predictable, still manages to be enjoyable.

reviews.review_title: Simply said, A Classic for all times
reviews.content: Cary Grant at his best.  Great chemistry with Rosalind Russell and a young and funny Ralph Bellamy. While chasing down an exclusive interview with a soon to be executed cop-killer, Grant does his best to keep Russell from marrying Bellamy.

reviews.review_title: One of Cary Grant's funniest performances
reviews.content: This is an incredibly fast-paced comedy, which in the typical screwball mode, pits newspaper editor Cary Grant against his star reporter, ex-wife Rosalind Russell, whom he wants to cover the execution of an anarchist before she goes off to marry Ralph Bellamy.  Cary Grant--Rosalind Russell--Ralph Bellamy.  I really don't need to say more.  If you like this, check out "His Favorite Wife" and "The Awful Truth".

reviews.review_title: Not my taste in my movies.
reviews.content: As much as I have been liking all the movies I've been watching, I just couldn't find myself enjoying this movie for a couple reasons. The sense of humor that they portrayed in this film wasn't my kind of humor in my opinion. I found a hard time connecting the with characters and feeling the emotion which is not usual the case for me when I watch movies. Also, in my opinion the plot line did not have enough substance to keep me as the audience engaged.

Overall a really entertaining movie. It had like a sugar high sensation to it like if you gave a toddler to many pixy stix, halarious at first but 90 minutes later its exhausting. Enough story to keep me till the end but I felt like I need a nap afterwards.

I love this movie. It's crazy funny and the actors are brilliant, carrying with them a lot of super fast dialogue weight. It's very witty, although some points the fast talking you can get lost in what they're saying.

I really enjoyed watching this movie, it is definitely now one of my favorites. the characters were perfect for this movie, especially Cary Grant i have always liked him in other movies that i have seen him in but this one had to be my favorite. i also felt like this movie kind of bring you in and it feels like you are there experiencing what they are experiencing.
They don't make films like this anymore. The chemistry between Grant and Russell is just out of this world amazing, which makes the fast hitting humor feel very natural and realistic.

Is this film about a journalist leaving the journalism business? Is this film about two ex lovers trying to move on to new relationships? Is it maybe a little about both? This very fast paced film will definitely keep you on your toes. It makes you want to find out what happens next. Is she going to go up north with her new fiancée? But then breaking news happens right in front of her face. Does she call up her old boss/ex husband to give him the news, or does she go to catch the train to Albany? Does she get herself caught right up in the mess or is she going to leave journalism behind her like she said in the beginning? You have to stick around until the end of the film to find out.

Howard Hawks created an intriguing screenplay that i could sort of relate to in a way. The jealousy that the main character, Walter, possesses is a common trait most individuals have. Most may not take it to the extent in which Walter did, but that is what makes this a fantastic screwball comedy. I also believe that Hawks chose talented actors and actresses to play the roles of his characters, and that is not an easy thing to do. Cary Grant(Walter) and Abner Biberman(Louie) were two amazing and very talented actors who played there parts extremely well. This movie has the ability to draw an audience in right from the start, and that in itself helps create a beautiful screenplay.

This movie is absolutely hilarious, a fantastic example of screwball comedy. Every single aspect is designed to highlight that comedy. The high key lighting, and the simple camera angles make sure that what you're looking at the most are the characters: And look at the characters, you should. The dialogue is the bulk of this movie, and the actors are what make it worth listening to, from their expressions to the absolutely wacky bravado behind their voices as they speak every single word. Even if there isn't a joke, you might still get a chuckle from the absurdity. The only thing really holding it back in my opinion is the general lack of eye candy (aside from character costumes), but that's relatively minor.

reviews.review_title: My Girl Friday a change of heart
reviews.content: I very much appreciated the leading lady in this film, Rosalind Russel who plays a ex-wife and also somewhat of an ex-reporter to Carey Grants persistent character of a leader in the press world. There are very few sets used in this film making it feel like a miniature sitcom involving various characters such as relentless reporters who are busy trying to get a scoop on corrupt politics and justice. The comedy is fast and witty which plays out nicely due to the constant use of the telephones that occupy the press office. I found the plot to be sort of ridiculous and understandably so which is why it is a screwball comedy. I doubt the motives between the characters would've resulted the same in real life but hey its a movie and that's what you pay for.

reviews.review_title: What will they do for the news?
reviews.content: The chaos of a newsroom makes it the best place for this movie to take place. A prison escape, a love triangle, and of course plenty of news business takes place mostly all in this setting. This builds a perfect story of frantic people moving every which way to get what they want. This movie really gives you the feeling of being in the newsroom as the action is taking place.

This movie is hilarious! Watching this movie was like being at the theater and listening to a sketch.. so funny!! I loved everything of this movie, but what it really made it enjoyable was the combination of fast sequences and the speed of the protagonists talking. My favorite character was of course Hildy. She was a volcano of energy and her personality made a huge difference in the whole story. When she says "I am a newspaperman darn it!" she means it!! Considering the time period and the presence of the Code, I believe her character is very innovative! Once again, one of the funniest screwball comedies I ever watched!
This part allows Cary Grant to act screwball comedy at the top of his game. What else do you need to know? Roz Russell holds her own, though, and the script is a corker. Lots of laughs.

This was a brilliant and hilarious movie. Cary Grant just flows into the camera with every movie he does. He makes movies fun. The chemistry with all the actors and actresses was superb! If you ever see this movie, you will fall in love with it

Maybe I have a soft spot for comedy, but I really thought for its time this movie was amazing. The quick choppy conversation leads to quick misunderstandings that cause you to laugh just a little bit. Cary Grant plays the roll of Walter to perfection. Even just the scene where he meets the new husband for the first time, the mistaken identity on the older man get the audiences to burst out laughing. Walter carries on during the rest of the movie with the audience knowing all he's trying to do is get Hildy back and this makes for the great comedic action. Everything that Bruce is put through adds so much irony. He looks like a really upstanding guy but as soon as Walter gets his tricks going it becomes just a series of amusing situations for the audience.

reviews.review_title: If you an actor or director, buy this movie.
reviews.content: Some of the greatest films are converted plays, and this is no exception. Probably the greatest example of cynical dialog ever filmed. The writing is superb, masterfully crafting a battle of jibes between two great actors. The other characters of the play, the story and setting, all seem of little importance to the rapid fire exchange between Grant and Russell. The speed, timing, and wit of the film are first rate. The speed of delivery is enough to make the dialog in West Wing seem like a slow tugboat ride to China. If you are in the film or theater biz you need to buy it, trust me. It amazing how casually the actors pull off the comic timing, you'll find yourself watching it again many times just to catch all the hyper-speed jokes. It definitely deserves a place in the top 50 films of our history if not the top twenty.

His Girl Friday is the story of a man who wants his wife back. What makes the film interesting, is what the man, Walter, played by Carey Grant, is willing to do in order to stop his ex-wife from marrying another man. Putting the weight of a man's life on Hildy's shoulders. Walter forces her to work together with his on a story about an escaped convict on death row. Becoming for more involved than she first intended, Hildy is swept up in a whirlwind involving her family and even the governor, all the while Walter uses the desperate situation for his own means. Does he succeed? There is nothing that stands out significantly in the cinematography. Perhaps the most distinguishing part of the image is the lighting.

His Girl Friday was a joy to watch! The acting from Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell was perfect for this film. It moves very fast and didn't have a dull moment. The film seemed modern in the way the plot advanced and the dialogue the two exchanged throughout. I enjoyed the outfit Rosalind Russell wore in the first scene, I think it showed her character right off the bat. If you're looking for a truly funny face paced screwball comedy this film is the one to watch.

I thought the angles in this film were an improvement from the thirties because the following and zooming in of characters was executed in a more precise way. Another thing I notice is that the "humor" they use in comedies back then pertains to a majority quirk are rather than a certain auidiance. I love the message in this movie. You might end up getting what you want but true love will always prevail. Also, gentlemen seem to always have things work out in terms of woman so maybe that is actually the message. Yeah end was not good, with Hildy getting back with Walter and they end up going to Albany for their honeymoon, which happens to be them going to protest. Not a traditional happy ending but a fitting scene that ties together the fact that Hildy is once again dragged to be with Walter.

reviews.review_title: FAST, SNAPPY Dialog. Well written, Well acted.
reviews.content: Most entertaining; The way Cary's character connives to trick Friday to stay on the story is navitete. Roz is hooked, but refuses to see the trap. By being drawn into the escape and subsequent hiding of the  prisoner,she has unknowingly sent herself back into the arms of the man who  refused to pop the question. Excellent acting accomplished by the prisoner (hiding in the roll top desk) and his girlfriend throwing herself out the window to distract the press pool located in the very same second story room. Reminds me of " Bringing up Baby " with a role reversal for Cary Grant. Whereas Kathryn Hepburn plays the trickster. For pure Fun, they're both must see films while humped up in the house with your wife/husband cold beer and popcorn.` Turn down the lights and ENJOY Hollywood at its best!!!!!!

Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell portray two reports on a hot story. Grant is the Editor of the paper and Russell's old flame. Now that Russell has moved on and is engaged to be married he will stop at nothing to get her back. The best shot he has to make this happen is to get her caught back up in the life of a reporter. Following a series of lies and mistruths Grant accomplishes just that and Russell is full steam ahead covering the escape of a criminal at the local jail. The movie is full of fast talk and tons of humor. Throw in a little slapstick here and there and you have a great movie anyone will enjoy.

His Girl Friday was filmed in 1940 and directed by Howard Hanks. This screwball comedy stars Rosalind Russell and Cary Grant. This film was more fast pace than I thought it would be, it's not an action movie but the way the dialogue is delivered it doesn't get boring like movies made in the 40's can get. This films shows how much comedy has changed through the years, back then they were able to make clever jokes without profanity.

His Girl Friday (1940), Howard Hawks
Although the movie focused on the boy chases girl tail, the significance of the movie highlighted three points of focus that weren't widely considered or accepted at the time of its publication. The first is breaking the gender bias because; the female reporter had the intelligence and acceptance to succeed in a predominantly male driven world. The second and third combines the sway of the media and how it can be used by political organizations.

It isn't your typical romantic comedy. We have a career woman Hildy who thinks she's ready to leave the hustle and bustle of the city to become a homemaker and wants to settle down. She attempts marry the quiet, well mannered and reserved Bruce but, Walter the jealous yet loveable ex-husband and boss of "The Post" believes this is her calling and does everything in his power to prevent her from leaving and causes mischief. I loved the way they had social awareness added into the film but didn't over power the main theme. I also enjoyed the lighting of the movie. It helped show the passion in the actors way they portrayed their characters. The lighting against the silverware gave the movie a old school glamour and just made the whole lunch scene look elegant against the busy background. I loved the way they styled her and made her seem bold, strong, independent one of the boys feel. They made Hildy one of a kind in the movie instead of the traditional 1940's housewife. I enjoyed it

Is it possible not to love Cary Grant?...Well, the answer is definitely NO! "His girl Friday" proves the unique talent of this gifted actor.I don't think that any other choice for the role of Walter Burns could be more suitable and I don't think that anybody could doubt that easily.The film is a classic story that focuses on the battle of the sexes in an absolutely clever way using as a vehicle for this cause "the battle of the two exes"!! Walter Burns is the big editor of a newspaper and has less than 24 hours in order stop the departure and the imminent marriage of one of his best reporters who ...by the way...happens to be his adorable ex-wife!In order to do that he invents every possible trick in order to keep her by convincing her,in the first place, just to postpone her departure for a couple of hours in order to cover a scoop..but that is just the beginning...!Rosalind Russell is absolutely perfect on the role of Hildy Johnson, Walter's ace reporter and ex-wife, using sophisticated and hilarious lines in order to outsmart Grant's intelligence and she proves to be an equal opponent on this perfect and romantic battle.In my opinion,the battle of the sexes can turn out to be an excellent way to unfold a love story under the condition that is promoted in a clever way and "His girl Friday" is just one of the best examples.The chemistry of Grant and Russell is radiant and depicts perfectly the electricity between the two exes who are too proud to admit their feelings to each other!One of the best of screwball comedies ever made ,"His Girl Friday", definitely deserves 10/10. The speed of the delivery of the lines is so quick that at some points it resembles a tennis match, where the audience can't see the ball!!But that's what makes this film that special DON'T MISS IT!

While this film was named a comedy while watching it at first I thought it was rather sad. Hildey is in the middle of divorcing someone that loves her still, a man is about to be sent to death, and nothing truly seems rather happy. but as I was watching I found the characters rather funny, molly very overdramatic hildey rather sarcastic, and the reporters frantic, and dumb. parts of the film are very funny, when theyre running from phone to phone, or out to eat, and the situation is rather awkward, while some are sad, When hildey is talking to the prisoner, and when Molly jumps out the window.

I usually hate "remakes," particularly remakes that screw around with the story. MacArthur and Hecht wrote their play, "The Front Page," about a newspaperMAN, Hildebrandt Johnson, and his relationship with his BOSS. Turning "Hildy," into "Hilda," and throwing into the reporter-editor relationship the complication that they are ex-spouses who are still in love (sort of), seems sappy.Yet, this is the exception. Having seen several versions of the original "Front Page," including the Pat O'Brien/Adolphe Menjou film and the later Jack Lemmon/Walter Matthau movie, I feel that the Rosalind Russell/Cary Grant "His Girl Friday" edition is in fact a huge improvement. The romantic subplot doesn't distract, it truly enhances the fun, and wit, and cynical sharpness, and allows Ralph Bellamy (the would-be new husband) to really get to join the comedy. Of all the adaptations of the play, this one is truly the wittiest, quickest, most rollicking, without losing the moments of darkness that do show up in the play.Don't miss the tiny gems: Cary Grant referring to a story about a suicide, Archie Leach (Grant's birth name); Grant telling "Bruce" that he looks like "that fellow, what's his name, Ralph Bellamy"; Billy Gilbert, John Qualen, and Gene Lockhart (as Sheriff Peter "pinky" "B for Brains" Hartwell) turning in perfect little performances in lesser parts.

This film is an absolute clinic in directing! You can set your watch to the pace Hawks sets with the film. An absolute gem! How is this not rated over 8.5?!?!? I mean come on folks there were a ton of great films that came out before 1985 contrary to popular belief. His Girl Friday is certainly one of them.

reviews.review_title: One of THE GREATEST comedies of all time.
reviews.content: If you haven't seen 'His Girl Friday' then you are in for a REAL treat! It has EVERYTHING: a fantastic plot, wit, intelligence, great acting, perfect comic timing, and romance! According to imdb trivia: "the normal rate of verbal dialogue in most films is around 90 words a minute. In His Girl Friday (1940), the delivery has been clocked at 240 words a minute." Indeed. There is SO MUCH comic goodness packed into every moment of this film that you might need multiple viewings to appreciate all of it. I've watched it many times over the years, and each time I usually catch a joke that I'd missed before. This film is the gift that keeps on giving!!Enjoy!!{One word of caution to ESL viewers: the actors talk REALLY fast. It's a challenge even for native English speakers with excellent hearing to catch every word, so you WILL need English Subtitles turned "ON."}

reviews.review_title: Traditional guy, but not traditional woman.
reviews.content: The film starts with Hildy walking into the press room looking very confidence. She asks the secretary where the boss (her ex-husband) is, once the secretary said do you want me to get him for you, she said no, I'll let him know myself. So right from the beginning of the film you get that this woman is in charge. Also having a female protagonist, itself was rare for the times. Statistically is rare now days also. But not as bad as before. As she was about to go meet with her ex-husband, Bruce, her now romantic lover offered his protection to her if things get rough. But she down played it by saying "oh I'll come running". As if she is a damsel in distress. But this was in a sarcastic way and the audience gets it right away. Once she gets to meet with her ex-husband, we quickly find out that she was the one who divorced him. Yet another indicator that she is the decision maker in the relationship. And later at the lunch scene we find out that the reason for her leaving him was probably because he slapped her. Thus the reason she chooses to end the relationship. After that the first incident or luck as one might put it, took place. Sweeney (a writer at the press room) was having a baby and this caused Walter (ex-husband) and the head of the new paper, to ask Hildy to stay and do the story for him. This is when we finally find out, why Hildy is there. This is the most important part in the movie, because Hildy is there with an agenda as we find out later in the film. Her decision to let Walter know that she is engaged, about to get married and leaving town tomorrow, sets in motions the events that follow. Once we put one and two together based on her actions towards Walter and Bruce, we quickly find out that she is trying to get Walter jealous. She still has feeling for Walter, but Walter is not the guy she can trust. Thus she uses Bruce, a well-rounded gentleman, to pull the strings and play with Walter's emotion. So as you can see, Hildy is in charge during the entire film based on her calculated decisions. A couple of seen that come to mind that was empowering for women were; when Hildy was being referred to as "newspaper man" meaning she is as good as any men or equal. When Hildy walked into a press-room with guys playing poker and calling them ladies and telling one of the guys that he could be her bridesmaid. And finally the scene where she tackled the guy to the ground. These were very empowering scenes considering the times. The character development in the film is also interesting. Hildy wants a traditional guy but she is not a traditional woman herself, nor is Walter. Thus at the end of the movie she finally goes to the honeymoon that she never had, but with some compromises.

reviews.review_title: Even if I'm not a fan of it, His Girl Friday still deserves my respect
reviews.content: I am not the right audience for this movie. I'm not sure what it was, but something about it just didn't catch my eye. reviews.review_title: A movie I adore but it's mild and bland
reviews.content: Recently, I watched Howard Hawk's His Girl Friday, and I absolutely loved it. It was genuinely funny, which already caught me by surprise, and it was a fast-paced and frantic film. The continuous dialogue and witty comments kept the film interesting. However, despite being a lovely film, it has its flaws. Seeing the film in 2017 and not in 1940 could alter the expectations I had for this film. The first one would be the relationship Walter had with Bruce, I'm uncertain how different my perspective would alter the 1940's context, but through my modern day perspective, I found it strange how understanding Bruce was of Walter and Hildy. I'm unsure whether that was supposed to show the Bruce was a bleaker man compared to Walter; that he was just a boring insurance man. Compared to Walter, who lies, manipulates, and cheats to get what he wants. Yet, I still find it odd that a man would let another man say he loves his future wife and acts horribly towards her without anything negative reflecting consequences. It's confusing how this was meant to be interpreted. Was this a way to show Walter as a caring and loving man from a comedic point of view? Or were the viewers supposed to think that Bruce was a chump who didn't deserve Hildy?Another thing I dislike about this film was the ending. When Hildy decided to remarry Walter despite him making empty promises, I was left with the feeling that their second marriage was going to end for the same reasons the first marriage ended. I disliked this so much because I truly thought that Rosalind Russell portrayed Hildy Johnson so brilliantly; she quickly became my favorite character in the film. A memorable and vibrant character, who was also the funniest. I was rooting for her to have a better, more suitable ending for her character. Having her start crying because of Walter's manipulation (where he immediately stopped wanting her as soon as she wanted him) halted the mood of the film. The ending was ruined for me personally, due to the fact that Walter spent the whole movie dominating her and standing in her way. Only to see Hildy being mistreated all the way through the end.

As someone who doesn't typically enjoy screwball comedies, for some reason I found this one slightly tolerable despite it being extremely fast paced it's definitely fun to watch Hildy and Walter excitedly yelling at one another. Although I did find it somewhat annoying at times it is still a great film and I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys a fast paced comedy with lots of twists and turns.

Cary Grant stars in this film. Is there anything else that needs to be said? Grant plays the former husband of newspaper reporter Russell. It is of course a romantic comedy, but one that is hilarious even today. The chemistry and dialogue between Grant and Russell rings genuine. Besides the romance, and the comedy, is the commentary the film makes about newspaper reporting and reporters. The key to this film is listening. This is not a popcorn picture where you can make comments to your viewing companions. If you talk you'll miss half of the jokes. So keep quiet and enjoy. Also Grant makes references to himself in a typically funny scene.

Cary Grant tries everything in his power to prevent his ex- wife from married again. I think it was wonderful movie and very funny. I had a really good time watching it. Cary doing everything to prevent Rosalind for getting married again but she trying every successful way to overcome him.

reviews.review_title: Utilizing media literacy skills to construct a reflection of the film
reviews.content: "Once upon a time" usually acts as a precursor to fairy tales and other fictional stories. Though beginning with this phrase, His Girl Friday presents no fairytale to the audience, but rather a romantic comedy sopping with farcical reporters, bickering, and trickery. Cary Grant's somewhat stiff physique relays a slight emotional distance from his costar, Rosalind Russell, but through other effects, such as parallelism, their film consortium rekindles. Hildy Johnson (Russell) and Bruce Baldwin (Ralph Bellamy), when juxtaposed to Hildy and Walter Burns (Grant), relate a safe, lackluster relationship. Hildy and Walter possess similar qualities that draw them closer chaotic scene after chaotic scene; they both smoke, express assertion, and lust for current news. Early in the film, when Walter treats Bruce and Hildy to a multi-intentioned lunch, opposites clarify as the men battle for Hildy's attention. Bruce chooses not to smoke but Hildy and Walter do; this emphasizes merely one of the various differences between the two men in Hildy's life. Mother's boy Bruce seems light-years away from independent Walter. Through the dynamic grouping of Hildy and Walter throughout the film, His Girl Friday foreshadows that they will end up together. This technique of grouping can provide the inclination or extrapolation to audiences of possible outcomes; and I find it beneficial to the plot of the film because relationships in my own life could be better if I find similarities within them. Puffing smoke will not save the relationship on its own, but the parallelism launches the plot and pulls the hard-hitting journalists together for their whirlwind of a chase.Hildy's dynamite of a character certainly asserts herself and stays one step ahead of all the shenanigans Walter tries to pull on naïve Bruce. Intelligent, independent Hildy portrays a more masculine woman, especially set in the forties, as she presents herself as career-oriented firecracker. Her souped up outfits complete with suits and fedoras flashes her personality as she works alongside men. Gender tension commonly appears in 1940s films, and His Girl Friday presents this with Hildy acting out of social norms, especially as a female reporter. Though Hildy contradicts many common characteristics of her time, she still gleams as the leading lady vulnerable to love. In the end, her heart goes to the man that closely reflects her qualities and fits into her intense personality best.Constant ringing of telephones, uneven window shades, and, at times, bustling reporters allude to chaotic undertones of the film; tumultuous conversing ensues as light-hearted murder looms. Layered banter and verbal sparring transform the film into a dialog-driven story, and much of the film contains scenes of confabulation rather than imagery and action. The scene at the very beginning of the film where Hildy tries to communicate to Walter that she will marry Bruce the next day works effectively within the plot because of its realistic nature. I also find that in conversation trying to explain myself and not knowing how to deliver my message quickly and to the point can further delay the inevitable. Especially evident through Mollie Malloy (Helen Mack) and her accusatory complaints, the film portrays journalists as cynical, hyperbolizing people, nearly dehumanizing them. Thus another chaotic-like facet of the film emerges through the façade of the journalists.Altogether the film presents a stream of laughs in an ocean of words as the characters juggle a murderer on the loose and controlling local officials.
It's very good motion picture, His Girl Friday, 1940 American screwball comedy, directed by Howard Hawks, starring Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell and featuring Ralph Bellamy and Gene Lockhart...

You'll need subtitles just to catch all the fast talking, transatlantic, double talk. 

Director Howard Hawks' romantic comedy His Girl Friday (1940) is very humorous, but also kind of too chaotic to even make sense. The entire movie is every character yelling over one another in hectic double talk sequences. Hawks' direction looks fine, but I found myself horribly lost in the pointless side stories and not really enjoying the stressful double talk and randomly serious drama that critiques unethical journalists that just lie for headlines. 

His Girl Friday wants to be a smart satire, romantic comedy, screwball comedy, and earnest melodrama and so it only accomplishes all of these to a moderate extent. It's too cluttered. The simultaneous conversations seems like a neat gag, but when it's the only real joke, His Girl Friday failed to make me belly laugh until Billy Gilbert's Joe Pettibone character showed up. His Girl Friday felt longer than 92 minutes, honestly.

It's sort of funny as writers Charles Lederer and Ben Hecht's script is clever and full of wit. But the endless talking around matters is obnoxious and incredibly hard to follow. The charismatic performances bring all this stream of conscious dialogue to life. His Girl Friday is not very romantic as Cary Grant is practically the villain, manipulating his ex-wife into getting back together with him in a relationship and at work. I found Grant's character sexist and overbearing like his only redeeming quality is that he's Cary Grant. 

Cary Grant is excellent as Walter Burns, but I don't like seeing Grant as a sexist newspaper editor. He's casually cruel and manipulative with his endless lies and deceptions. He is fun, but Grant is better as the nice everyman rather than a fast talking con man. Everyone talks quickly with Grant's same Transatlantic accent, so Grant doesn't even stand out vocally as much as normal.
 
Rosalind Russell is charming, but gullible herself as Hildy Johnson. I feel like she's introduced as a smart independent woman, but she gives up her family life and fiancee for a man that treats her terribly. If all she wanted was a career, that's fine, but Grant gives her no reason to fall in love as they're barely on screen together. Ralph Bellamy is fun as a completely gullible fool named Bruce Baldwin. He's almost too stupid to believe. Abner Biberman is fun as the con artist and thief Louie.

John Qualen is touching as the wrongly convicted death row escapee Earl Williams. He's far too sincere for a comedy as these serious scenes drag the tone and pace down considerably. Helen Mack is shockingly moving as Mollie Malloy out of nowhere. She's the only person that cares about the man about to be wrongly sentenced to death. Billy Gilbert is hilarious as Joe Pettibone, who delivers the pardon of the criminal. His boisterous laugh and charming personality are very funny as the clueless fool. He elevates the film considerably.

Gene Havlick's editing could have cut this down into something slicker. It's fairly slowly paced for how much talking takes place and how short His Girl Friday is actually. Joseph Walker's shots are pretty flat as it looks like a play rather than a dynamic film. It's all wide shots with a few choice close-ups and medium shots to freshen things up. I thought the camera held too long in the same place to really hold my attention. 

Composers Sidney Cutner, Felix Mills, and Ben Oakland wrote a fairly forgettable score that's slightly lively, I suppose? Lodge Cunningham impressively mixes all the voices together so that you can clearly hear what each person is saying despite them talking over one another. Robert Kalloch gives Rosalind Russell a crazy patterned suit and Cary Grant a neat tailored suit. Everyone else has regular suits of the era.

In all, I am a bit disappointed by His Girl Friday. It is funny, but not nearly as hysterical as it should have been.
This is one of my favorite movies of all time. The dialogue is great, the jokes are sharp, and so are the clothes. Wicked good.

This was a fun little surprise! What made this movie work and what made it truly as fun as it was was how fast that dialogue was spit out-I'm really in awe of the universe this movie sets up where every single person is witty and talks a mile a minute. I really don't think it would work even at 75% speed. It was a fun little story and Rosalind Russell's character really was something special for a movie made in 1940. I loved the gender politics in the film and the matter-of-fact dark comedy worked really well. That being said, the plot and characters and filmmaking really weren't anything to write home about but I did enjoy this movie.

Amazing dialogue. Witty.  Phenomenal cast. Outstanding performances.  Original and fun ever time you watch it.  A top 5 of all time. ❤️❤️❤️
classic by every measure! one of the all time enjoyable films

A classic ‘screwball' comedy, or in simpler terms, a quirky comedy. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russell both bring their A game here with brilliant chemistry throughout.

The comedic elements come from a pretty good script from Charles Lederer but it's the performances from both leads that ignite the film. 

The narrative shifts back and forward and the tone is interesting as the film progresses. It's a good film at a satisfactory length too. 

One of Grants best. Definitely recommend.

Grant and Russell invest in their roles and provide a few brilliant moments, but this romantic comedy coasts on charms and fast dialogue to cover up the uninteresting conflict not pertaining to the main character's relationships. It seems that the filmmakers and actors sought to show off more than anything else in order to deliver speed rather than thoughtfulness. Grant's character is a charming scumbag and much of the film seems antiquated and aged rather than timeless. The screenplay weakens in the second half as it focuses on tying up the plot rather than offering the amusing quips in high volume earlier on. His Girl Friday is a decent time-killer, but not one that modern audiences are particularly missing out on.

Packed full of incredibly fast-paced dialogue, characters constantly speaking over one another, and an incredibly charming performance from Grant, His Girl Friday is probably one of the greatest romantic comedy classics that isn't really part of pop culture mainstream these days. There is always something happening, though Hawks dedicates a surprising amount of time towards darker moments that haven't seeped into the film's reputation - criticisms of the police and judicial systems, and particularly the press and yellow journalism (a woman literally attempts suicide due to the mischaracterizations of a group of backroom wordsmiths, and it stops the film dead with sobriety for a moment). The plot is convoluted, but that's part of the point - that Grant's Walter would go to such bizarre lengths to create the opportunity to preserve his relationship with Hildy (Russell), as faking phone calls gradually escalates to harboring a convicted killer. The fast-paced dialogue and consistent one-liners and brisk jokes often make this film seem like a slightly more fleshed out, romantic version of a Marx Brothers film, though championed by a magnetic performance from a single actor rather than a trio. Funny, short, and distinctive, His Girl Friday is still an absolute must see for both fans of classic film and those just looking for some entertainment value. (4/5)

The cycle of abuse in black and white still hold up today. This movie does a great job painting manipulation as romantic. The news paper guy moves about in an amusing manor tho so that was a laugh. Good dialogue. Very Gilmore girls.
i'll say it, rosalind russell is a dime & cary grant does his best to keep up in this fast-talking adventure
One of the finest works of Cary Grant and Rosalind Russel.
Dialogue is just insane.  They deliver so much information in such a short time and you don't even realize they are doing it.  Movies just moved faster back then and it shows here.

Watched once and found movie to be both very enjoyable and easy watching. Grant and Russel play high-anxiety ridden/believable news reporters. The dialogue speed is fast, but easy to follow as it is suspenseful. Scenery is mostly office, after hours card playing,
And several outside night scenes.
Suspenseful, comedy, and dramatic at times. Must watch

Marvelous acting, brilliant writing, unparalleled directing -- and without a doubt zero the greatest example of the leading lady and the leading mom being shown and treated as equals. About 75 years (at least) ahead of its time in honestly realistic gender equality. A truly wonderful, classic piece of cinema, and arguably the greatest slapstick comedy in Hollywood history.

(Also, too: "Take Hitler and stick him on the funny pages!")

This is now one of my favorite movies, one of the funniest films I've ever seen and one of the most terrifyingly realistic perspectives on love that I've ever witnessed. The dialogue is biting and made me laugh out loud multiple times and the murderer plot brings great tension between the characters. The film ends rather unexpectedly, though perhaps it should have been easy to see coming.

Everything works perfectly in this re-working of the classic The Front Page. Female acting greats Katharine Hepburn, Claudette Colbert, Ginger Rogers and Irene Dunne are all said to have turned down the role of Hildy Johnson. What a lucky break for Rosalind Russell and us. She's fabulous! And, Cary Grant was never better.

I never had a clue about the existence of this movie, and I watched it for the sake of an assignment. The casting is appreciable as all the actors did serve justice to their roles with a touch of comical approach, especially the protagonists. The one-liner of the movie being 'you can keep an enthralling occurrence off a journalist but never a journalist off an enthralling occurrence!', I guess the movie did what it intended to. Though the style of humor incorporated isn't timeless, the satire worked in favor of the subject. The best thing I can say about this movie is it never bored me though it wasn't successful in forcing me to postpone micturating until this screwball flick!
This was honestly such a great movie. The speed of the dialogue made it even more entertaining, and it was fun to keep up with the pace.

"Take Hitler and stick him on the funny pages" A great screwball comedy from 1940 starring the always great Cary Grant. The scene where Walter mistakes another man for Hildys fiance is hilarious. This film has the perfect blend of stage play comedy, murder and drama.

The most polished, most natural, most endearing screwball comedy to grace the silver screen or, for that matter, any screen. Cary Grant and Rosalind Russel play ex-husband and wife newshounds bound by a shared passion for brainy repartee, enduring chemistry and a passion for getting the big scoop. Grant nearly dominates but Russell spars blow for comic blow. The template for a hundred rom-com wannabes.
It may not be the actors best but it sure is them at their best.

A justifiably famous film, a great screwball comedy that helps to define the genre.  It has fast-talking craziness, duplicity, self-delusion, double meanings, brilliant cast-off lines, relentless skewering of sensational journalism, and much more.  Rosalind Russell and Cary Grant are outstanding, with Grant chewing up the scenery at an unrelenting and brilliant pace.

rt_summary: When hard-charging New York newspaper editor Walter Burns discovers that his ex-wife, investigative reporter Hildy Johnson, has gotten engaged to milquetoast insurance agent Bruce Baldwin, he unsuccessfully tries to lure her away from tame domestic life with a story about the impending execution of convicted murderer Earl Williams. But when Hildy discovers Williams may be innocent, her reporter instincts take over.
